hypotheses.source_question: Do E3-brane instantons wrapping specific three-cycles in χ = −6 elliptically fibered CY3s generate superpotential textures that simultaneously stabilize moduli AND enforce the correct Yukawa rank hierarchy (top ≫ bottom ≫ electron) required to survive Levels 2–3 filtering?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that E3-brane instantons wrapping specific three-cycles in χ = −6 elliptically fibered CY3 threefolds generate superpotential contributions that directly enforce Yukawa coupling rank hierarchies (top ≫ bottom ≫ electron), and this instanton-Yukawa filter reduces the viable SM-like vacuum candidates from 39 (Level 0) to ≤5 (post-Level 3).
hypotheses.mechanism: E3-instantons wrapped on three-cycles C generate non-perturbative superpotential terms W_inst ∝ exp(−2πT_C) coupling Higgs to chiral fermions. The exponent T_C encodes both geometric data (cycle volume) and modular weights of matter fields. Only three-cycles with specific intersection numbers with divisors in the Chow ring produce instanton terms that simultaneously (i) maintain rank-3 Yukawa matrices Y_u,d,e and (ii) yield eigenvalue ratios m_t:m_b:m_τ ≥ 100:10:1. Cycles failing this constraint either collapse the rank (non-invertible matrices, textures incompatible with three generations) or produce inverted hierarchies. Thus E3-instantons causally constrain the selection of viable three-cycles, and hence viable flux choices (Level 2) and Yukawa sectors (Level 3).
hypotheses.prediction: For ≥70% of the 39 χ = −6 elliptically fibered CY3s examined, the instanton-Yukawa filter (three-cycles supporting rank-3 Yukawa with correct hierarchy) reduces the set of valid three-cycles from the full H₃(CY₃, ℤ) basis to ≤2 inequivalent cycles per model. Globally, ≤5 models will survive application of this filter while maintaining moduli stabilization compatibility (Level 5 prerequisite).
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If >50% of the 39 models exhibit either (i) zero three-cycles capable of generating rank-3 Yukawa matrices with observed SM eigenvalue ratios, or (ii) >10 inequivalent three-cycles all yielding viable hierarchies with similar Kähler moduli constraints, the hypothesis is refuted: the instanton-Yukawa filter is either vacuous (too restrictive or absent) or non-discriminating (too permissive). Additionally, if the number of models surviving the filter is >10, the instanton-Yukawa mechanism is not the primary discriminant between Level 0 and Level 3 candidates.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Instanton-Yukawa filter reduces viable three-cycles per model by ≥80% (from mean of ~20 in full H₃ basis to ≤4). Post-filter model population shrinks from 39 to ≤5 (128× compression ratio, equivalent to ≥95% elimination of Level 0 candidates).

experiment.approach: For each of the 39 χ = −6 elliptically fibered CY3s in the Kreuzer-Skarke database, compute the homology H₃(CY₃, ℤ) using toric or mirror-symmetry methods; systematically enumerate three-cycles and compute instanton-generated superpotential contributions; extract Yukawa coupling matrices from the matter-field coupling structure and apply rank-hierarchy filters (m_t/m_b ≥ 100, m_b/m_τ ≥ 10); identify which three-cycles survive this instanton-Yukawa filter and count how many distinct cycles remain per model.
steps: For each of the 39 models: obtain polytope data and mirror geometry from Kreuzer-Skarke database or CYTools.
Compute H₃(CY₃, ℤ) using toric cohomology (Dwork/Griffiths-Dolgachev) or mirror symmetry period computation. Extract integral basis of 3-cycles.

For each three-cycle C: compute the Kähler modulus T_C (volume form integrated over C, or read from toric fan data); determine the divisor classes (elements of H^{1,1}) that intersect C non-trivially.

For each non-zero intersection pairing (C ∩ D ≠ 0): identify the chiral matter multiplet associated to the divisor D in the elliptic fibration context (standard Kodaira classification + matter curves).
Compute the instanton coupling constant λ_C ∝ exp(−2πT_C). Construct the superpotential terms W_inst = Σ_C λ_C × (product of matter fields with correct intersection multiplicities).
Extract the Yukawa coupling matrix entries by taking derivatives of W_inst with respect to Higgs fields and chiral fermions: Y_u,d,e = ∂³W_inst / ∂Φ_H ∂Φ_f ∂...
Compute singular-value decomposition of each Y_u,d,e. Extract eigenvalues λ₁ ≥ λ₂ ≥ λ₃.

Test filtering criteria: (i) rank(Y_u,d,e) = 3? (ii) λ_u1/λ_u2 ≥ 100 AND λ_u2/λ_u3 ≥ 10? (iii) λ_d1/λ_d2 ≥ 10 AND λ_d2/λ_d3 ≥ 2? (iv) λ_e1/λ_e2 ≥ 10 AND λ_e2/λ_e3 ≥ 2? If YES to all four, mark three-cycle C as 'viable'.
For each model: count total three-cycles in H₃ basis (cardinality N_H3), and count viable three-cycles post-filter (cardinality N_viable).
Compute filtering ratios: (N_H3 − N_viable) / N_H3 per model. Count how many models have N_viable ≤ 2 and ≤ 5.

Cross-check: for each viable three-cycle in each model, verify that the Kähler moduli T_C are consistent with LVS/KKLT moduli stabilization (i.e., τ_C > O(1) in units where string scale ~ 1; explicit flux quantization check if data available).
Generate summary table: (Model ID, N_H3, N_viable, filter ratio %, Kähler-stable?, Surviving to Level 5?).
tools: CYTools (Kreuzer-Skarke polytope + toric geometry)
SageMath / Macaulay2 (cohomology computation, lattice operations)
Mirror symmetry Picard-Fuchs solver or toric duality (compute H₃ periods)
Custom Python: instanton coupling evaluation, Yukawa matrix extraction, SVD, eigenvalue-ratio test
RefineDB or similar (cross-reference elliptic fibrations and divisor class data if available)
LVS/KKLT moduli-stabilization constraint checker (homemade or via existing CY database metadata)
experiment.estimated_effort: 3–4 weeks compute + code development. Bottleneck: H₃ computation for all 39 models (~5 hrs/model assuming mirror symmetry is available; ~200 hrs total). Instanton coupling + Yukawa extraction: ~2 hrs/model once H₃ is in hand (~80 hrs). Analysis + filtering: ~40 hrs. Validation + cross-checks: ~30 hrs.
experiment.data_requirements: Kreuzer-Skarke polytope database (public); CYTools database (elliptic fibrations, Kodaira types, divisor classes); mirror geometry periods or toric cohomology data; literature values for chiral matter curves on elliptic fibrations (Cvetic-Lin-Taylor); observed SM Yukawa eigenvalue ratios (m_t ≈ 172 GeV, m_b ≈ 4.7 GeV, m_τ ≈ 1.78 GeV → ratios 36:10:1 at M_Z scale, or 80:20:1 in some running schemes; use conservative thresholds 100:10:1).
experiment.expected_positive: For ≥28 of 39 models (≥72%): N_viable ≤ 2, and model count N_surviving ≤ 5 with all five models showing Kähler-stable T_C values and rank-3 Yukawa with correct hierarchy. This would constitute strong support for the instanton-Yukawa filter hypothesis and would validate the causal claim that E3-instantons enforce SM structure.
experiment.expected_negative: If <15 of 39 models show N_viable ≤ 2, or if N_surviving > 10, or if many models have zero viable three-cycles (emptyset for viable cycles), the filter either does not exist or is not the primary discriminant. If eigenvalue-ratio tests are satisfied by >10 three-cycles per model with widely disparate T_C values, the instanton coupling does not constrain the problem and other mechanisms (flux quantization, metric conditions) dominate.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The distribution of viable three-cycles per model is uniform/random in N_viable; the mean N_viable is ≥5 and does not significantly differ from N_H3/4 (i.e., ~25% of H₃ basis). The instanton-Yukawa filter provides no additional discriminatory power beyond existing rank or chirality constraints.
experiment.statistical_test: One-sample t-test on the population {N_viable / N_H3} across 39 models: test H₀: μ = 0.25 vs. H₁: μ < 0.10 (i.e., filter reduces viable cycles to <10% of H₃ basis on average). α = 0.05. Expected effect size: μ_observed ≈ 0.05–0.08 (assuming hypothesis true), σ ≈ 0.03. Required power = 0.90 to detect d = (0.25 − 0.07) / 0.03 ≈ 6, which is highly significant with n = 39. Additionally, compute exact binomial test on counts: 'How many of 39 models have N_viable ≤ 2?' Under H₀ (uniform distribution), P(N_viable ≤ 2 | H₀) is small; compute via permutation test or beta-binomial if heterogeneity is present.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Effect size: ratio of viable to total three-cycles drops from 25% (null expectation under uniform sampling) to ≤8% under the hypothesis. For n = 39 models and assuming σ(N_viable / N_H3) ≈ 0.04, a t-test achieves 90% power to detect Δμ ≈ 0.06 (i.e., distinguish 0.25 from 0.19 with α = 0.05 two-sided). However, the primary success criterion is structural: ≤5 models survive the full filter (count-based), equivalent to ≥87% of models being eliminated. This requires a binomial test: under H₀ (each model has fixed p_survive ≈ 0.5), the probability that ≤5 of 39 survive is <0.001; under H₁ (p_survive ≈ 0.13), this probability is >0.80.
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Sample size: n = 39 models (fixed by Kreuzer-Skarke database + CYTools scan, not a design choice). Assumed effect: mean filtering ratio Δ(N_viable / N_H3) ≈ −0.17 (from 0.25 to 0.08), σ ≈ 0.04. One-sample t-test with α = 0.05 (two-sided) achieves power >0.95 to detect this effect (t-statistic ≈ −6.5, highly significant). For the count-based criterion (≤5 models survive), assume Binomial(n=39, p=0.13 under H₁); this yields P(X ≤ 5) ≈ 0.75, acceptable for a discovery study. Conservative scenario: if true effect is smaller (filtering ratio drops only to 0.15), power drops to ~0.80; still adequate. Convergence criterion for instanton coupling computation: iterate T_C evaluations until relative error in W_inst < 10⁻⁶ (standard precision for algebraic geometry symbolic computation).
limitations: H₃ computation relies on available mirror symmetry data or toric cohomology; for models without explicit mirrors in the literature, computation may require numerical period integration (higher error bars).

Yukawa coupling extraction assumes a concrete choice of divisors D_i and their associated matter curves; different divisor class representatives may yield different coupling constants (ambiguity in labeling). This is mitigated by using Kodaira fiber classification, which uniquely specifies matter curves, but requires cross-validation with Cvetic-Halverson-Lin and Weierstrass model literature.

Eigenvalue-ratio thresholds (100:10:1 for up-type, 10:2:1 for down/lepton) are idealized from pole masses at M_Z; running to different energy scales (e.g., GUT scale, SUSY scale) shifts ratios. Sensitive to choice of renormalization scheme. Mitigation: use multiple threshold sets and report robustness.

Instanton coupling λ_C ∝ exp(−2πT_C) assumes purely exponential suppression; worldsheet instanton contributions and multi-instanton effects are neglected. Only O(e^{−2πT}) terms are included; higher-order terms O(e^{−4πT}) are suppressed and ignored. This is standard in moduli stabilization but introduces systematic uncertainty (~10%) in coupling magnitudes.

Moduli stabilization compatibility (Kähler stability check) requires flux quantization data, which is not always publicly available for all 39 models. Fallback: use generic parametric constraints (τ_C > 1) rather than explicit flux computation.
No explicit vacuum stability or Higgs potential analysis; assumes that if Yukawa textures are correct, vacuum is stable (not verified independently).

Only Level 3 (chirality + rank structure) is tested explicitly. Levels 1, 2, 4, 5, 6 are partially addressed via cross-checks but not systematically filtered in this experiment. This is acceptable for a discovery study but limits claims about full filtering hierarchy.
Computational cost is manageable but H₃ computation for non-hypersurface models may be intractable without external data. Assumes CYTools or mirror symmetry tables contain relevant models.
experiment.requires_followup: The experiment is purely computational and does not require wet-lab work. However, full validation requires two computational follow-ups: (1) Explicit Weierstrass model verification for models identified as surviving the filter: compute the discriminant locus, confirm divisor class structure, and cross-check Yukawa matrices against F-theory literature (Cvetic-Halverson-Lin). (2) For ≤5 surviving models, perform full moduli stabilization (LVS or KKLT) to confirm that the Kähler moduli T_C values obtained from the instanton-Yukawa filter are consistent with flux quantization and the Kahler cone. If these two follow-ups confirm the computational predictions, the instanton-Yukawa mechanism is established as the causal filter, and the work is complete without wet-lab input.

hypotheses.source_question: Do coalgebra morphisms between Hopf algebras in F-theory compactifications provide a systematic method to classify and filter SM vacuum candidates by enforcing consistency constraints on gauge-sector symmetry breaking and moduli stabilization?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that coalgebra morphisms between Hopf algebra representations of the SM gauge sector and its GUT parent provide a necessary and sufficient filtering criterion that eliminates at least 60% of χ = −6 Kodaira-classified candidates while preserving all known realistic SM vacua, thereby converting ad-hoc Level 1–6 filters into a unified algebraic obstruction.
hypotheses.mechanism: The SM gauge algebra su(3) ⊕ su(2) ⊕ u(1)_Y arises as a consistent coalgebra subalgebra of a parent Hopf algebra (SU(5) or SO(10)) only if the comultiplication respects specific symmetry-breaking patterns and topological constraints encoded in the fiber discriminant and the polytope combinatorics of the base. Coalgebra morphisms that fail to preserve the coproduct structure on SU(5) → SM breaking correspond to vacua with inconsistent hypercharge embeddings, forbidden Yukawa textures, or incompatible moduli stabilization. By requiring that every proposed SM vacuum admit a coalgebra morphism satisfying nested compatibility conditions (spanning hypercharge assignment, chirality quantization, Yukawa rank structure, and discrete symmetry preservation), we encode all six filter levels into a single algebraic obstruction. Morphisms that cannot be continuously deformed without breaking these conditions mark vacua as topologically unstable.
hypotheses.prediction: For the 39 χ = −6 elliptically fibered polytopes in the CyTools scan, coalgebra morphism enumeration (via SageMath Hopf algebra module) will classify at most 15 (±3) models as admitting morphisms compatible with all six filter levels (hypercharge embedding, 3 generations, Yukawa rank, proton decay protection, moduli stabilization, swampland). This represents a 62% ± 8% reduction from the naive Kodaira count of 39, and will include all known realistic SM vacua (if any exist in this dataset) while excluding models failing explicit flux-choice or metric constraints from prior literature. Effect size: Cohen's h (proportion difference) = 0.62 with 95% CI [0.54, 0.70].
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If coalgebra morphism filtering eliminates fewer than 45% of candidates (i.e., ≥22 models survive all morphism conditions), OR if it eliminates a model known from prior work (Braun, Cvetic, Anderson) to possess a valid SM vacuum with moduli stabilization and realistic Yukawa texture, the hypothesis is refuted. Additionally, if the filtered set contains models where no SU(5) ↪ Hopf algebra embedding exists that is compatible with the χ = −6 discriminant locus, coalgebra formalism is insufficient for vacuum classification.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: ≥60% elimination rate (proportion ≤0.40 survival); Cohen's h ≥ 0.40 (medium effect); AIC reduction of ≥15 points vs. baseline Kodaira classifier; AND zero false negatives among benchmark SM vacua (sensitivity ≥ 95% if ground truth exists).

experiment.approach: Build a computational pipeline that formalizes su(3) ⊕ su(2) ⊕ u(1)_Y and SU(5) as explicit Hopf algebras with coproduct rules, then enumerate all coalgebra morphisms between them compatible with the discriminant and fiber structure of each of the 39 χ = −6 polytopes in the CyTools database. For each polytope, test whether admitted morphisms satisfy nested constraints corresponding to Levels 1–6; tabulate survival rates and compare against (i) naive Kodaira counts and (ii) known realistic vacua from literature (Braun, Anderson, Cvetic benchmarks).
steps: Download the 39 χ = −6 reflexive polytopes from Kreuzer-Skarke database; extract Hodge numbers and Weierstrass model coefficients for elliptic fibrations via Sage polytopes module.

Construct explicit Hopf algebra representations: (i) SU(5) with standard coproduct Δ(T^a) = T^a ⊗ 1 + 1 ⊗ T^a + structure-constant terms; (ii) SM subalgebra su(3) ⊕ su(2) ⊕ u(1)_Y with coproduct determined by GUT-breaking patterns (e.g., SU(5) → SM via adjoint Higgs VEV).

Formalize coalgebra morphism conditions: a map φ: SU(5) → su(3)⊕su(2)⊕u(1)_Y is a coalgebra morphism iff (φ ⊗ φ) ∘ Δ_SU(5) = Δ_SM ∘ φ. Encode as polynomial identity in SageMath CommutativeAlgebra module.

For each polytope: (a) compute the discriminant locus in the base (toric ideal); (b) extract fiber types (Kodaira classification); (c) enumerate Hopf subalgebras of SU(5) consistent with the fiber discriminant structure using SageMath's Hopf algebra decomposition tools.

Filter morphisms by Level constraints: (L1) U(1)_Y embedding uniqueness (dim cokernel = 0); (L2) chirality index = ±3 mod discrete symmetries; (L3) rank(Yukawa) = 3 with texture zeros (use exterior algebra); (L4) discrete symmetry preservation (kernel structure); (L5) moduli-stabilization compatibility (check compatibility with Kähler cone of polytope); (L6) swampland constraint checks (use known bounds from literature: Ooguri-Vafa, distance conjecture).
Tabulate: for each polytope, number of coalgebra morphisms surviving each level; cumulative elimination rate; consistency with prior Braun/Cvetic/Anderson results if available.
Statistical test: binomial test of proportions (H₀: survival rate = 100% vs. H₁: <40%), with Benjamini-Hochberg correction for multiple comparisons across 39 polytopes.
Sensitivity analysis: vary assumed effect size (60% vs. 50% vs. 70% elimination); recompute using two independent Hopf algebra libraries (SageMath + GAP) to validate implementation.
Generate visualization: scatter plot (polytope ID vs. survival count across levels); heatmap (polytope × level, colored by pass/fail); dendrogram of morphism-space topology.

Cross-check: for any polytope with >20 surviving morphisms, manually inspect Weierstrass model to confirm or refute existence of known SM vacuum (via literature search or contact with Braun/Anderson group).
tools: SageMath (Hopf algebra module, CommutativeAlgebra, polytopes interface)
GAP (Groups, Algorithms, Programming; independent Hopf algebra verification)
CyTools (Calabi-Yau database query API; polytope data retrieval)
Kreuzer-Skarke database (χ = −6 polytope dataset, ~500k entries)
Macaulay2 (polynomial ideal membership for coalgebra morphism verification)
Custom Python script (orchestration, filtering logic, output aggregation)
Literature benchmark: Braun et al. (2010) GUT breaking models; Anderson et al. (2010) heterotic SM vacua count; Cvetic et al. (2019) F-theory Yukawa couplings
experiment.estimated_effort: 4–8 weeks compute time (parallelizable over 39 polytopes on 16-core cluster; Hopf algebra enumeration ~1–4 hours per polytope; morphism filtering ~0.5–2 hours per morphism set). Code development and testing: 2–3 weeks (researcher time). Total wall-clock: ~6 weeks single-machine or ~10 days on high-performance cluster.
experiment.data_requirements: Kreuzer-Skarke database (~100 MB for full dataset, but <10 MB for χ = −6 subset); CyTools cache (existing Kodaira classifications, ~50 MB); prior literature on realistic SM vacua (Braun, Anderson, Cvetic papers; ~10 candidate models for ground-truth testing).
experiment.expected_positive: Coalgebra morphism filtering reduces candidate set from 39 to 12–18 models (60% ± 8% elimination); filtered set includes all known benchmark SM vacua (zero false negatives); remaining candidates cluster into identifiable families (e.g., by Hodge numbers, fiber type) suggesting shared topological structure; morphism-space topology reveals hierarchical obstruction pattern matching the Level 1–6 hierarchy empirically.
experiment.expected_negative: Coalgebra morphism filtering eliminates ≥22 models (survival ≥56%, below 45% threshold), indicating morphism conditions are either too weak or misaligned with physical constraints. Alternatively, filtered set excludes a model known to possess a valid SM vacuum with all Levels 1–6 satisfied, indicating the Hopf algebra formalism misses an essential physical constraint. Or: morphism enumeration yields >100 surviving candidates per polytope on average, suggesting the algebraic structure provides minimal discriminatory power.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The fraction of χ = −6 elliptically fibered polytopes admitting coalgebra morphisms compatible with all six filter levels equals the fraction surviving naive Kodaira + chirality-index filters (i.e., >90%, with no significant additional reduction). Equivalently, coalgebra morphisms provide zero informative constraint beyond Kodaira classification and do not unify the Level 1–6 filtering hierarchy.
experiment.statistical_test: Two-tailed binomial test (n=39 polytopes; p_null = 0.90 survival; p_alt = 0.40; α = 0.05; expected survival under H₁ ≤ 15 models). Power calculation: with n=39 and assumed p_alt=0.40, statistical power >0.95 to reject H₀ (p_null=0.90). Report exact binomial CDF and 95% Clopper-Pearson CI for survival proportion. Additionally, report AIC of coalgebra-morphism model vs. baseline (Kodaira + chirality) to quantify parsimony gain.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Elimination of ≥23 polytopes (survival ≤16/39 = 41%); Cohen's h = 0.62 (difference between 90% null and 40% alternative proportions); BIC difference ≥10 vs. Kodaira-only model; sensitivity ≥0.95 for retaining ground-truth SM vacua (if ≥3 exist in dataset).
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Binomial test with n=39 polytopes, α=0.05 (two-tailed), null p=0.90, alternative p=0.40. Type II error β≈0.03, power 1−β≈0.97. This is adequately powered to detect the predicted 60% reduction (15/39 survival). For any polytope failing the morphism test, we cannot distinguish 'no morphism exists' from 'morphism exists but is computationally hard to find'; we mitigate by running morphism enumeration twice with independent randomized search seeds. Convergence criterion for morphism enumeration: exhaust all degree-≤10 polynomial morphisms, or timeout at 4 CPU-hours per polytope (justification: higher-degree morphisms unlikely in physics practice).
limitations: Hopf algebra formalism assumes exact gauge symmetry at high scale; explicit flux breaking and Higgs mechanisms introduce perturbative corrections not captured by coalgebra structure.

Morphism enumeration is computationally NP-hard in the degree and rank of the algebra; we impose degree-10 cutoff, which may miss morphisms requiring higher-degree polynomial relations (unlikely but not impossible).
CyTools Kodaira classifications are heuristic (dependent on toric divisor resolution); some fiber types may be misclassified, introducing noise into the ground-truth benchmark.

No existing literature provides an explicit catalog of all realistic SM vacua in χ = −6 polytopes, so false-negative validation relies on sparse prior work (Braun, Anderson, Cvetic); systematic ground truth unavailable.
Coalgebra morphism framework assumes SU(5) or SO(10) GUT parent; other breaking patterns (e.g., Pati-Salam, flipped SU(5)) not tested. Generalization to non-GUT F-theory constructions unclear.
Swampland constraints (e.g., distance conjecture, WGC) are approximate heuristics; encoding them as exact polynomial constraints may be overly restrictive or incorrect.

Cross-validation against heterotic spectral-cover results (Braun et al.) limited by structural differences between heterotic and F-theory (different moduli spaces, different moduli-stabilization mechanisms).
experiment.requires_followup: This is a primary computational experiment. However, full validation of the hypothesis requires: (i) explicit metric computation (Donaldson algorithm or Kähler-Einstein solver) for the 12–18 surviving models to verify that Level 5 (moduli stabilization) and Level 6 (swampland) constraints are actually satisfied (wet-lab equivalent: construction of the LVS/KKLT solutions); (ii) phenomenological Yukawa computation on a representative subset (e.g., GL=12/D₆ polytope) to confirm that morphism-compatible models yield realistic CKM matrices, proton lifetime, and neutrino masses; (iii) comparison with Braun's explicit bundle computation (heterotic line-bundle stability) and Cvetic's F-theory flux quantization to ensure coalgebra filtering is not introducing artificial agreement.

hypotheses.source_question: Do explicit Riemann surface topologies and their moduli spaces constrain the existence and selection of stable Standard Model vacua in heterotic and F-theory compactifications, and can this constraint be formalized as a topological obstruction to SM Yukawa textures?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that Riemann surface genus and marked-point structure of the toric base causally constrains the space of stable spectral covers in heterotic and F-theory compactifications, and that topological obstructions derived from genus-dependent bundle slope conditions eliminate ≥30% of SM-like candidates before Yukawa rank computation.
hypotheses.mechanism: The spectral cover of a GUT gauge group (SU(5) or E₆) must be a double or triple cover of the Riemann surface base of an elliptically fibered CY3. The genus g of the base and its automorphism group G_aut directly constrain the genus g_cover of any cover via Riemann–Hurwitz, which in turn determines the space of holomorphic vector bundles via Bogomolov–Gieseker slope stability. Lower genus bases (g < 3) and bases with few marked points admit fewer stable covers with the slopes μ ∈ [−1, 1] required for anomaly cancellation; higher genus bases and those with orbifold singularities admit larger moduli spaces, but their automorphism groups may forbid Wilson line embeddings compatible with hypercharge quantization. This directional constraint—base topology → spectral cover existence → bundle slopes → Wilson line breakings—eliminates candidates not through metric-dependent Yukawa rank, but through algebraic obstruction.
hypotheses.prediction: Among the 39 χ = −6 elliptically fibered CY3s in the Kreuzer–Skarke database, those with toric base genus g ≤ 2 will retain ≤25% of SU(5) spectral covers in the stability locus (slope condition μ ∈ [−1, 1]), compared to ≥60% retention for bases with g ≥ 3. Quantitatively: the filtering power of topological obstruction (genus + marked-point count) will reduce the candidate pool from 39 to ≤27 models before Yukawa rank computation, a 30% pre-filter that correlates with ≥0.7 Spearman rank-order agreement with the true SM-viable set identified by Levels 3–5 filters.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If >50% of bases with g ≤ 2 retain ≥50% of SU(5) covers in the stability locus, or if topological filtering (based on genus and automorphism group alone) eliminates <15% of the 39 models and shows Spearman ρ < 0.4 against the Level 3+ filtered set, the hypothesis is refuted. Equivalently, if genus alone is statistically independent (χ² test, p > 0.05) of the number of stable covers per base, the causal link is severed.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Explained variance in cover-count reduction ≥20% by genus + marked-point features; ≥30% reduction in candidate pool via topological pre-filter; Spearman ρ ≥ 0.7 between topologically filtered and Yukawa-filtered subsets.

experiment.approach: Computationally extract toric base topology (genus, automorphism group, marked points) for all 39 χ = −6 elliptically fibered CY3s using CyTools geometry parsing. For each base, enumerate SU(5) and E₆ spectral covers, compute their existence condition (Riemann–Hurwitz) and stability locus (Bogomolov–Gieseker slope condition μ ∈ [−1, 1]). Quantify filtering power at each stage and correlate topological invariants against downstream Yukawa rank and Wilson line compatibility.
steps: Parse the 39 CY3 toric fan data from Kreuzer–Skarke database and CyTools output; extract the elliptic base as a toric surface or toric threefold quotient.

For each base, compute genus g via adjunction formula on toric divisors; identify marked points (singular fibers, toric points, quotient singularities) and compute the automorphism group G_aut (via toric symmetries and canonical bundle invariants).
Enumerate all multi-covers (degree 2 and 3) of the base that respect the orbifold structure. For each cover, apply Riemann–Hurwitz to compute cover genus g_cover and branching data.

For each candidate cover, compute the space of rank-5 (resp. rank-8) vector bundles via Chern class constraints (c₁, c₂ from GUT embedding). Restrict to the slope-stability locus: μ(E) ∈ [−1, 1] using Bogomolov–Gieseker, parameterized by moduli coordinates on the cover.
Count the number of connected components in the stable bundle moduli space for each cover. Flag covers with empty or 0-dimensional moduli as unstable.

For each stable cover, enumerate Wilson line embeddings (1-dimensional flat connections up to gauge equivalence). Check consistency with SU(5) → SM breaking and hypercharge quantization (Y = ⅓(B−L) − T₃ orthogonal to U(1)_Z).
Cross-tabulate: base genus g, automorphism group order |G_aut|, marked-point count, and number of stable covers per base. Test correlation (Spearman rank, χ² independence test) against base topology.
Compute Chern-Simons index for each stable cover to predict chirality |η₃| from c₂(E)·[base]; compare to Levels 2 and 3 filter criteria (exactly 3 generations mod discrete symmetries).

Identify topological obstructions: genus ranges or automorphism group structures that admit zero stable covers or are incompatible with all hypercharge-consistent Wilson lines. Document these as formal exclusions.

Quantify filtering power: (count of models eliminated by topological obstruction) / 39 = pre-filter efficiency. Compare to efficiency of Levels 1–3 filters in the heterotic literature (e.g., Anderson et al. 2012).
Compute Spearman rank-order correlation between the topologically pre-filtered set and the known SM-viable set from Braun/He/Ovrut or the GL=12/D₆ case study (if available).
tools: CyTools (geometry parsing, Hodge numbers, toric fan analysis)
SageMath / Macaulay2 (toric varieties, automorphism group computation, Riemann–Hurwitz)
cohcalg / Wolfram Mathematica (Chern class and slope-stability calculations on toric surfaces and covers)
Custom Python pipeline (spectral cover enumeration, moduli space dimension via deformation theory, Wilson line orbit enumeration)
Kreuzer–Skarke database (39 χ = −6 polytopes and associated elliptic fibrations)
HE He/Lukas ML predictor (optional cross-check: compare topological filter against ML-predicted SM viability)
experiment.estimated_effort: 4–8 weeks (parallelizable geometry parsing + cover enumeration + stability computation for 39 bases; bottleneck is spectral cover enumeration and slope-stability boundary determination per base).
experiment.data_requirements: Kreuzer–Skarke polytope list (39 entries with χ = −6 and elliptic structure); CyTools output for each (Hodge numbers, toric fan, Kahler cone); optionally, published SM-viable subsets from Braun/He/Ovrut or other groups for correlation benchmark.
experiment.expected_positive: Genus g and marked-point count show χ² ≥ 5 (p < 0.05) correlation with number of stable SU(5) covers per base. Topological pre-filter eliminates 27–32 of 39 models. Remaining ~10 models show Spearman ρ ≥ 0.65 agreement with Levels 3–5 filtered sets from heterotic literature. At least one genus constraint (e.g., g ≤ 1 forbids E₆ covers with stable rank-8 bundles) is formally proven via Riemann–Hurwitz + slope-stability bounds.
experiment.expected_negative: Genus and automorphism group structure show no statistically significant association (χ² < 2, p > 0.1) with stable cover count. Topological pre-filter eliminates <10% of models. Spearman ρ < 0.4 between topologically and Yukawa-filtered sets, indicating that base topology is orthogonal to SM viability. Alternatively, all 39 bases admit equally rich families of stable covers, making genus informationally empty.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: Riemann surface genus g, marked-point structure, and automorphism group G_aut are independent of the number and stability locus of spectral covers for GUT embeddings. Equivalently, the distribution of stable cover counts is homogeneous across all 39 bases regardless of toric base topology.
experiment.statistical_test: Pearson χ² test of independence: base genus (binned as g ≤ 1, 2 ≤ g ≤ 3, g ≥ 4) vs. stable cover count (binned as 0, 1–2, ≥3), α = 0.05. Spearman rank-order correlation between topological invariants (principal component of genus + log|G_aut| + marked points) and stable cover count, α = 0.05, two-tailed. Fisher exact test to check if topological pre-filter's predicted SM-viable set overlaps ≥70% with gold-standard set (if available), α = 0.05.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Cramer's V ≥ 0.35 (medium effect) for χ² independence test; Spearman ρ ≥ 0.65 for correlation with Yukawa filters; ≥30% relative reduction in candidate count via topological obstruction. In terms of sample size: n = 39 models with fully computed spectral cover moduli for each provides ~90% power to detect Cramer's V = 0.35 at α = 0.05.
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Sample size is fixed at n = 39 (all χ = −6 elliptically fibered CY3s in Kreuzer–Skarke). With 39 observations, a Pearson χ² test with 2 × 3 contingency table (genus bins vs. stable cover bins) has ~85% power to detect Cramer's V = 0.35 (medium effect) at α = 0.05, two-tailed. For Spearman rank correlation, n = 39 gives ~80% power to detect ρ = 0.40 at α = 0.05. For count-based filtering (proportion of models eliminated), binomial test with n = 39, p₀ = 0.5 (null: topological filter removes ≤50%), observing k ≥ 12 eliminations gives >90% power to reject H₀ at α = 0.05. Convergence criterion for spectral cover enumeration: complete all irreducible covers up to degree 5 and all slope computations to precision ±10⁻⁶.
limitations: Spectral cover enumeration is computationally intensive; only SU(5) and E₆ covers are treated (omitting other GUT groups, which may have different topological constraints).
Slope-stability computation depends on choice of Kähler cone, which may be incompletely specified from toric data alone; results assume generic (or Calabi–Yau) Kähler class.

Wilson line breaking from SU(5) to SM requires explicit flux choice; topological pre-filter does not compute Yukawa textures, only existence and slope stability of the bundle. Correlation with Levels 3–5 is assessed post-hoc via literature comparison, not re-computation.
Marked points on toric bases are identified algorithmically (toric singularities, special fibers); some orbifold data may be lost if the elliptic fibration is not resolved at all points.
No direct experiment on cosmic strings, domain walls, or other topological defects from the CY3 geometry; filtering is purely algebraic.
Requires access to published SM-viable sets from Braun/He/Ovrut or equivalent; if unavailable, correlation step (Spearman ρ) must be deferred to follow-up work.
experiment.requires_followup: Wet-lab analog: construction of explicit heterotic spectral cover bundles for the top-ranked topologically filtered candidates, followed by Yukawa coupling computation via holomorphic section enumeration. This would validate the topological predictions (Levels 1–2) against actual Yukawa textures (Level 3). Alternatively, an F-theory string compactification (Weierstrass model, resolved quotient, explicit metric) could be constructed for one representative base to verify that topological pre-filtering correctly predicts moduli stabilization (Level 5) and cosmological viability (Level 6).

hypotheses.source_question: Does the choice of orbifold discrete symmetry group in heterotic string compactification deterministically constrain the emergent gauge algebra structure and chirality index, or is the relationship underdetermined without additional data (metric, Wilson lines, bundle choice)?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that the discrete symmetry group of a heterotic orbifold deterministically constrains the emergent gauge algebra structure to contain su(3) ⊕ su(2) factors via fixed-point geometry and Kaluza-Klein reduction, independent of bundle moduli and Wilson line choices, explaining the observed ubiquity of SM-like factors in χ = -6 elliptically fibered Calabi-Yau threefolds.
hypotheses.mechanism: Orbifold singularities partition the E₈×E₈ lattice into orbifold-invariant sublattices via discrete group actions; fixed-point resolution and blow-up geometry restrict the Kaluza-Klein modes available for gauge embedding, forcing a subset of E₈ to decompose into su(3) ⊕ su(2) ⊕ u(1)^k at the singularity locus. This filtering occurs at the level of lattice algebraic geometry before any metric, bundle stability, or Wilson line choice is made. Bundle and Wilson line data can only *further constrain* this already-filtered algebra, never enlarge it beyond the orbifold-geometric maximum.
hypotheses.prediction: For ≥70% of ℤₙ orbifolds (n ∈ {3,4,6,7,12}) acting on T⁶ or K3×T² with χ = -6 compatible fixed-point structure, the maximal gauge algebra achievable via E₈ lattice reduction on the singular geometry will include su(3) ⊕ su(2) as a direct summand; this maximum will be independent of bundle choice and will match or exceed the observed gauge algebra in ≥80% of published heterotic orbifold models for those point groups.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If <50% of the studied orbifold singularities (across all tested ℤₙ families) exhibit su(3) ⊕ su(2) as a consequence of orbifold geometry alone (via lattice reduction without bundle input), or if the maximal orbifold-geometric algebra is *systematically smaller* than the gauge algebra observed in published models for the same orbifold type (indicating that bundle/Wilson choices enlarge the algebra, contradicting the causal claim), the hypothesis is refuted.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: >70% of orbifold singularities yield su(3)⊕su(2) from geometry; ≥80% concordance between maximal orbifold algebra and published model spectra for the same point group; Cramér's V ≥ 0.4 for association between orbifold type and SM-like gauge factor presence

experiment.approach: Systematically compute the maximal gauge algebra achievable via E₈×E₈ lattice reduction on the singular (unresolved) geometry of representative ℤₙ orbifolds, then compare to: (i) the same orbifolds after explicit blow-up and resolution, and (ii) published heterotic orbifold model spectra for validation. Use a computational framework combining toric geometry, lattice computation, and orbifold cohomology to isolate orbifold-geometric filtering power from bundle/Wilson-line choices.
steps: Select a stratified sample of ℤₙ orbifold singularities: n ∈ {3,4,6,7,12} acting on T⁶ and K3×T² (justify by occurrence in heterotic literature and χ = -6 compatibility check via holonomy and action on holomorphic 3-form).
For each orbifold, compute the fixed-point set F using explicit matrix representations of the group action; classify fixed points by dimension (0, 2, 4-dimensional fixed loci).
Compute the orbifold-invariant sublattice Λ_inv ⊂ E₈ for each point group by solving G(λ)=λ for all λ ∈ E₈ roots; decompose Λ_inv into irreducible representations of G.

Apply Kaluza-Klein reduction on the singular (unresolved) geometry: compute the zero modes of the heterotic supergravity action restricted to orbifold-invariant deformations. Extract the Lie algebra factors present in the low-energy spectrum from the KK tower.
Repeat step 3-4 after explicit blow-up resolution of singularities; compare the resulting gauge algebras to quantify the effect of resolution on spectrum.

For a subset of orbifold types (n=3,6,12), cross-validate against published heterotic orbifold models from papers 1002.1081, 2011.04113, and Vafa/Weigand databases: extract reported gauge groups and compute overlap with predicted orbifold-geometric maximal algebra.

Quantify filtering power: compute the fraction of E₈ root vectors eliminated by orbifold invariance at each singularity type; compare to fraction eliminated by bundle stability conditions (from heterotic literature) to isolate orbifold causal contribution.

Perform a non-orbifold control: compute the same quantity for smooth K3 and quintic Calabi-Yau geometries (no discrete symmetry); verify that SM-like factors occur at significantly lower frequency (<30%) in the control.
Test association between orbifold point group and presence of su(3) ⊕ su(2) using contingency table analysis (Cramér's V, χ² test, alpha=0.05).
tools: SageMath / Macaulay2 for toric geometry and orbifold singularity computation
PALP (Kreuzer-Skarke database query interface) for polytope and K3 fibration data
GAP (Groups, Algorithms, Programming) for discrete group representation and fixed-point set enumeration
Custom Python script for E₈ lattice root enumeration and orbifold-invariance filtering (root systems package)
Heterotic string literature database (arXiv papers, CyTools output) for published model spectra validation
R or Python scipy.stats for contingency analysis and effect size computation
experiment.estimated_effort: 4-6 weeks: ~1 week orbifold singularity setup and fixed-point computation (all n); ~2 weeks KK reduction and lattice filtering (implementation and validation on 2-3 orbifold types); ~1 week cross-validation against literature and control geometry computation; ~1 week statistical analysis and result synthesis.
experiment.data_requirements: E₈ root system (standard reference, ~240 roots); explicit matrix representations of ℤ₃, ℤ₄, ℤ₆, ℤ₇, ℤ₁₂ acting on T⁶/K3×T² (from heterotic literature, e.g., Dixon-Vafa-Weigand review); published heterotic orbifold model spectra (extracted from arXiv papers and maintained databases); CyTools scan results for χ = -6 Calabi-Yau polytopes (Kreuzer-Skarke database).
experiment.expected_positive: ≥70% of ℤₙ orbifold singularities studied yield su(3) ⊕ su(2) as a lattice-level consequence of orbifold invariance (before blow-up or bundle choice); this maximal algebra matches or contains the observed spectrum in ≥80% of published heterotic orbifold models for the same point group; control experiment on smooth K3/quintics shows <30% occurrence of SM-like factors, establishing causal link to discrete symmetry.
experiment.expected_negative: <50% of orbifold singularities exhibit su(3) ⊕ su(2) from geometry alone; published heterotic orbifold spectra are *systematically larger* than the predicted maximal orbifold-geometric algebra (e.g., extra gauge factors appear only after bundle/Wilson choice), indicating that orbifold topology does not deterministically drive SM-like structure; contingency analysis shows no significant association (Cramér's V <0.3, p>0.05).
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The emergent gauge algebra structure is conditionally independent of orbifold discrete symmetry group given the choice of bundle moduli and Wilson lines. Stated formally: P(su(3)⊕su(2) in spectrum | orbifold type) = P(su(3)⊕su(2) | bundle, Wilson lines). The observed ubiquity of SM-like factors in χ = -6 CY3s is an artifact of bias toward SM-like models in the literature or an intrinsic feature of χ = -6 topology, not of orbifold discrete symmetry.
experiment.statistical_test: Two-proportion z-test (comparing fraction of orbifolds with SM-like factors to control geometry baseline); Cramér's V contingency test for association between orbifold type and su(3)⊕su(2) presence (alpha=0.05, two-tailed). For continuous gauge algebra dimension: two-sample t-test comparing maximal orbifold-geometric dimension to control geometry dimension (alpha=0.05, power=0.90). Bonferroni correction applied across ≥12 orbifold types tested.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Proportion difference ≥20 percentage points (e.g., 70% in orbifolds vs. 50% in control) requires ~100 orbifold samples at 80% power; effect size Cohen's h ≥0.42. For contingency: Cramér's V ≥0.40 (medium effect) with n≥100 cells across contingency table. For gauge dimension: Cohen's d ≥0.6 (medium-to-large effect) across point groups.
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Sample size: assume 15–20 distinct orbifold singularities (stratified by ℤₙ, n∈{3,4,6,7,12}); each orbifold tested on T⁶ and K3×T² variants → ~35 orbifold geometry configurations. For each configuration, compute maximal algebra deterministically (no variability); therefore power is determined by ability to detect true association, not sampling variability. Assume baseline frequency of SM-like factors in smooth K3/quintics ≈30% (conservative prior); target detection of 70%+ in orbifold cases → effect size h≈0.42, requiring ~100 model cross-validations from literature at 80% power. Contingency analysis on 5 point group categories × 2 geometry types × presence/absence of su(3)⊕su(2) → 20-cell table; Cramér's V ≥0.4 at alpha=0.05 achievable with n≥80–100 published orbifold models.
limitations: Heterotic orbifold literature is incomplete and biased toward models with 'nice' spectra (SM-like), creating selection bias in cross-validation step; mitigated by including all arXiv preprints in targeted keywords, not only published papers.

Orbifold singularity structure is highly sensitive to choice of embedding in T⁶/K3×T²; generalization across embeddings requires exhaustive enumeration (computationally expensive) or sampling (introduces variability); mitigated by focusing on standard embeddings from literature (e.g., standard action on coordinates).

KK reduction on singular (unresolved) geometry is not fully rigorous in standard physics textbooks; derivation relies on formal limit arguments and orbifold cohomology (well-defined mathematically but not all steps automated); mitigated by validating against resolved geometry and published heterotic calculations.

χ = -6 selection criterion may be a confounder: perhaps χ = -6 CY3s are more likely to admit elliptic fibrations with specific Kodaira types that independently favor SM gauge algebras; this is addressed by control experiment on smooth K3 with arbitrary χ.

Bundle moduli space and Wilson line space are infinite-dimensional; cannot exhaustively verify that bundle/Wilson choices never enlarge the orbifold-geometric maximal algebra; mitigated by checking top ~100 published models and using theoretical argument (lattice sublattice ordering).
experiment.requires_followup: Wet-lab equivalent: explicit heterotic string worldsheet conformal field theory (CFT) construction on one or two representative orbifolds (e.g., ℤ₆ on K3×T², with GSO projection and bundle choice). Compute the full spectrum (both fermionic and bosonic) using character methods and orbifold partition function; verify that the predicted maximal orbifold-geometric algebra from this computational study is indeed achieved when bundle/Wilson moduli are chosen optimally. This would upgrade the computational inference from 'lattice algebra structure' to 'full CFT spectrum,' confirming that the algebraic filtering power translates to physical mode content. Estimated effort: 2–3 months for one CFT model (requires expertise in heterotic worldsheet methods, not widely automated).

hypotheses.source_question: In F-theory and heterotic compactifications, does the Pati-Salam gauge symmetry SU(4)_c × SU(2)_L × SU(2)_R naturally emerge as an intermediate stage in symmetry breaking chains that yield Standard Model-like vacua, and what topological and flux conditions discriminate Pati-Salam models that successfully break to the SM from those that do not?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that the Pati-Salam gauge symmetry SU(4)_c × SU(2)_L × SU(2)_R acts as a topological-lattice filter that reduces the viable SM-vacuum candidate set by at least 60% when applied upstream of Levels 1–3 of the filtering hierarchy, and that models carrying embeddings of Pati-Salam without lattice obstructions to hypercharge breaking have a 3–5× higher probability of surviving the Yukawa rank and chirality filters than those lacking such embeddings.
hypotheses.mechanism: Pati-Salam emerges geometrically in F-theory and heterotic models when the Kodaira fiber spectrum contains SU(4) and SU(2)× SU(2) factors that can be embedded as sub-algebras within the full gauge algebra derived from the elliptic fibration structure or spectral cover. The presence of a compatible Pati-Salam lattice structure (specifically, the embedding of U(1)_Y as a diagonal in SU(2)_R ⊗ U(1)_B−L without Abelian anomalies) acts as a necessary geometric precondition for breaking chains that yield SM-like representations. Models satisfying this precondition are already constrained to a topologically restricted subspace of moduli, reducing the entropy of vacuum choices and thereby increasing the probability that flux-choice and Wilson-line breaking yields correct chirality and Yukawa structure. Conversely, models that fail the Pati-Salam lattice test face additional algebraic obstructions when attempting to construct SM-compatible breaking chains, making them less likely to survive Levels 2–3.
hypotheses.prediction: Of the 39 χ = −6 elliptically fibered CY3 models in the Kreuzer-Skarke database scan, at most 15 (38 ± 5%) will pass the Pati-Salam lattice obstruction test (existence of SU(4)_c ⊂ G with anomaly-free hypercharge embedding). Among these 15 Pati-Salam-carrying models, ≥9 (≥60%) will admit breaking chains to SM-like gauge algebras with 3 chiral generations and Yukawa rank structure; among the 24 that fail the Pati-Salam filter, ≤4 (≤17%) will survive equivalent Level 1–3 tests, yielding an odds ratio of ≥3.5 for SM viability conditioned on Pati-Salam compatibility.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If the odds ratio for SM-level viability (Levels 1–3 passing) conditioned on Pati-Salam lattice compatibility is ≤1.5 (i.e., models with Pati-Salam embeddings are not substantially enriched for SM properties), or if >30% of non-Pati-Salam models achieve Level 1–3 compatibility via alternative breaking chains without invoking Pati-Salam intermediates, the hypothesis is refuted. Additionally, if cross-validation on the Braun-He-Ovrut spectral-cover polytope set fails to recover their known O(100) SM survivors within the subset passing the Pati-Salam filter, the causal claim is falsified.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Odds ratio ≥3.5 for Level 1–3 viability given Pati-Salam lattice compatibility (equivalent to ≥60% survival rate among Pati-Salam models vs. ≤17% among non-Pati-Salam, Fisher's exact p < 0.05, n=39); alternatively, ≥2-fold enrichment in achievable chirality indices (|χ/2 − net_chirality|) among Pati-Salam-compatible models when controlling for Hodge numbers.

experiment.approach: Perform a systematic computational census of all 39 χ = −6 elliptically fibered CY3s from CyTools scans. For each model, extract the full Kodaira fiber spectrum and gauge algebra; identify SU(4)_c and SU(2)_L × SU(2)_R sub-algebras within the Weierstrass or toric description. Test each model for the topological-lattice conditions required for Pati-Salam compatibility (anomaly-free hypercharge U(1)_Y = diag in SU(2)_R ⊗ U(1)_B−L). Partition the 39 models into two cohorts: Pati-Salam-compatible (n_PS) and non-compatible (n_non-PS). For each cohort, enumerate admissible flux choices (F-theory) or Wilson lines (heterotic) and compute Level 1–3 viability metrics (correct gauge algebra, correct hypercharge, chiral generation count). Cross-validate findings on known SM survivors from Braun-He-Ovrut literature.
steps: Step 1: Extract Kodaira fiber classification and gauge algebra G for each of the 39 χ = −6 elliptically fibered CY3s using CyTools/Magma. Document all SU(4), SU(2), and U(1) factors.
Step 2: For each model, systematically search for embeddings of Pati-Salam sub-algebra SU(4)_c ⊗ SU(2)_L ⊗ SU(2)_R within G using root-system and weight-lattice algorithms (e.g., LiE, GAP4).

Step 3: For each candidate Pati-Salam embedding, test the lattice obstruction: compute U(1)_Y as a U(1) factor in the commutant of SU(2)_L ⊗ SU(3)_c and verify that a diagonal U(1) ⊆ SU(2)_R ⊗ U(1)_B−L can be embedded anomaly-free using the Green-Schwarz mechanism (compute the anomaly matrix for the full model).
Step 4: Classify each model as Pati-Salam-compatible (PS) or not based on Step 3 result. Tally n_PS and n_non-PS.

Step 5: For each PS-compatible model, enumerate flux choices (F-theory) or Wilson-line choices (heterotic) that break Pati-Salam → SM. Compute Level 1–3 metrics: (i) correct gauge algebra (SU(3) ⊗ SU(2) ⊗ U(1)_Y), (ii) absence of anomaly from embedded hypercharge, (iii) chirality index and comparison to observed 3 generations.
Step 6: For each non-PS model, perform direct SM-breaking enumeration (not through Pati-Salam intermediate) and compute Level 1–3 metrics using the same protocol.
Step 7: Construct a 2 × 2 contingency table: (Pati-Salam compatible: yes/no) vs. (Level 1–3 viable: yes/no). Compute Fisher's exact test p-value and odds ratio.
Step 8: Cross-validate on Braun-He-Ovrut polytope set: identify which known SM survivors carry Pati-Salam intermediate structures and check fraction recovered by PS filter.

Step 9: Sensitivity analysis: recompute filtering power under relaxed/tightened definitions of 'Pati-Salam compatible' (e.g., require explicit SU(4)_c or allow implicit embeddings) and of 'Level 1–3 viable' (e.g., allow non-integer hypercharge quantization).
tools: CyTools (Kreuzer-Skarke database queries, elliptic fiber identification)
Magma/SINGULAR (toric geometry, Kodaira fiber classification)
GAP4 + LiE (Lie algebra computations, root systems, weight lattices, anomaly matrices)
Macaulay2 (sheaf cohomology for chirality index computation, line bundle charges)
Custom Python pipeline: graph-based sub-algebra search, lattice obstruction solver, flux enumeration and rank computation
Braun-He-Ovrut spectral-cover database (cross-validation target)
experiment.estimated_effort: 6–10 weeks full-time equivalent: ~3 weeks data extraction and Kodaira classification, ~2 weeks Pati-Salam embedding search and lattice tests, ~2 weeks flux/Wilson-line enumeration and Level 1–3 metric computation, ~1 week statistical analysis and cross-validation, ~1 week sensitivity analysis and documentation.
experiment.data_requirements: CyTools Kreuzer-Skarke database (public); polytope descriptions (toric coordinates); Braun-He-Ovrut spectral-cover models (published literature or author-provided dataset); Magma/Singular/GAP4 installed locally or via SageMath/CoCalc; ~100 GB workspace for intermediate fiber and flux-choice data.
experiment.expected_positive: Among the 39 models, 12–18 are classified as Pati-Salam-compatible. Of these, ≥10 yield SM-like gauge algebras and 3-generation structure after flux/Wilson-line breaking (≥60% survival). Among 21–27 non-PS models, ≤4 independently satisfy Level 1–3 (≤17%). Fisher's exact two-tailed p-value < 0.05; odds ratio point estimate ≥3.5 with 95% CI not including 1.5. Cross-validation: ≥70% of known Braun-He-Ovrut SM survivors carry identifiable Pati-Salam intermediates.
experiment.expected_negative: Among the 39 models, either (i) ≥25 are classified as Pati-Salam-compatible (filter too permissive), or (ii) <8 are PS-compatible and <5 survive Level 1–3 (filter too restrictive). Pati-Salam-compatible models show ≤50% Level 1–3 survival, while non-PS models show ≥15% survival (odds ratio ≤1.8, Fisher p > 0.1). Cross-validation: <50% of Braun-He-Ovrut survivors carry Pati-Salam intermediates, indicating alternative pathways dominate.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: Pati-Salam lattice compatibility is statistically independent of Level 1–3 viability (SM-like breaking). Formally, P(Level 1–3 viable | PS-compatible) = P(Level 1–3 viable | ¬PS-compatible), and the odds ratio OR = 1.
experiment.statistical_test: Fisher's exact test (two-tailed) on 2 × 2 contingency table with α = 0.05; 95% confidence interval on odds ratio computed via log-log method. Given expected cell frequencies from prediction (e.g., PS-compatible & viable ≈ 9, PS-compatible & non-viable ≈ 6, non-PS & viable ≈ 4, non-PS & non-viable ≈ 20), Fisher test is appropriate for small n.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Odds ratio ≥3.5 at α = 0.05, two-tailed, n = 39 (all models in cohort). For 60% vs. 17% success rates in equal-sized groups, power ≈ 85% via Fisher's exact test (post-hoc). Alternatively, ≥2-fold enrichment in mean chirality-index precision (defined as |χ/2 − net_chiral_asymmetry| averaged over flux choices) in PS-compatible cohort vs. non-PS (paired t-test, α = 0.05).
experiment.statistical_power_notes: All 39 χ = −6 elliptically fibered CY3s are included (no sampling; exhaustive census). Fisher's exact test does not assume cell normality and is exact for small n. Expected cell counts: PS-compatible & Level 1–3 viable ≈ 9–10; PS-compatible & non-viable ≈ 5–6; non-PS & viable ≈ 3–4; non-PS & non-viable ≈ 20–21. Post-hoc power calculation: assuming true OR = 3.5, p = 0.6 (PS-compatible success), and marginal PS prevalence = 0.4, Fisher test achieves ~85% power (two-tailed α = 0.05). Convergence for topological computations (root-system searches, anomaly-matrix rank): iterate algebra-embedding search until >99.9% of candidates enumerated (verified by comparing to theoretical maximum from character dimension counting).
limitations: Kodaira fiber classification from toric data is algorithmic but may miss singular or non-standard fibers; manual inspection of anomalous cases is required.
Pati-Salam lattice test relies on Green-Schwarz anomaly cancellation in heterotic frame; F-theory interpretation requires compatible base geometry (not checked in this experiment).
Flux/Wilson-line enumeration is combinatorially explosive; capping search at first N viable breaking chains per model may undercount survivors.
Chirality computation assumes trivial vector bundle; non-trivial bundles or non-minimal models may alter generation count.
Cross-validation against Braun-He-Ovrut data depends on completeness and accessibility of their spectral-cover models; publication bias toward survivors may inflate baseline PS prevalence.
Statistical test has limited power for detecting OR < 2 with n = 39; larger database (e.g., full Kreuzer-Skarke or other χ values) would strengthen claims.
No explicit metric or moduli-stabilization check (Level 5–6); conclusions apply only to topological and flux filtering.
experiment.requires_followup: Wet-lab equivalent: none direct (this is purely mathematical/computational). However, to claim full viability of surviving models, explicit metric computation and moduli stabilization (KKLT/LVS, Level 5) is required. Computational proxy: implement a lattice-based moduli-stabilization consistency check (e.g., verify that the volume form and Kahler cone are compatible with the flux superpotential in the surviving models). Additionally, a follow-up would compute the Yukawa matrix rank and texture-zero structure for the top 5–10 PS-compatible, Level 1–3-viable models to validate Level 3 more rigorously.

hypotheses.source_question: Do the moduli-space geometric properties of elliptically fibered K3 surfaces (Weierstrass model structure, singular fiber classification, Picard lattice rank) deterministically constrain which Calabi-Yau threefolds admit Standard Model-like gauge algebras with correct hypercharge embeddings and stable Yukawa textures, independent of explicit flux choice?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that the Picard lattice rank and discriminant form of the base K3 surface in an elliptically fibered Calabi-Yau threefold causally constrains the existence and embedding of the hypercharge U(1)_Y factor, such that K3 lattices with rank ≤ 18 and discriminant form containing no (−2)-vectors fundamentally obstruct correct SM hypercharge embeddings independent of flux choice.
hypotheses.mechanism: The K3 Picard lattice generates the geometric Mordell-Weil lattice of the elliptic fibration; this MW lattice must contain a primitive vector whose orthogonal complement in the full transcendental lattice embeds the SU(3)×SU(2) Lie algebra and admits a rank-1 Abelian extension realizing hypercharge quantum numbers. K3 lattices with rank-deficient discriminant forms (e.g., those forbidden from having type II singular fibers by Nikulin's theory) eliminate the geometric degrees of freedom needed for correct U(1)_Y embedding. Thus K3 geometry acts upstream of Weierstrass discriminant: lattice rank constrains which Kodaira fiber types are possible, which in turn gates U(1) charge assignments.
hypotheses.prediction: Among the 39 elliptically fibered χ=−6 CY3s, K3 fibers with Picard rank ≥ 19 will exhibit ≥ 3 distinct primitive Mordell-Weil vectors admitting hypercharge embeddings with correct (Q_Y = 1/3 mod charges achievable for up-quarks, Q_Y = −2/3 for down-type), whereas K3s with rank ≤ 18 and trivial-discriminant-form torsion will admit ≤ 1 such embedding (p < 0.01, Fisher's exact test), with explained variance of Picard rank on U(1)_Y embedding multiplicity ≥ 45%.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If K3 Picard rank ≤ 18 with trivial torsion for ≥ 3 of the 39 CY3s nevertheless admits ≥ 2 geometrically distinct hypercharge embeddings (verified by explicit construction of primitive MW vectors and their orthogonal complements), the hypothesis is refuted: K3 lattice structure alone does not gate U(1)_Y choice.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Picard rank explains ≥ 45% of variance in the number of allowed U(1)_Y embeddings (R² ≥ 0.45); Fisher's exact test on contingency table (rank ≤18 vs >18 × embedding count ≤1 vs >1) yields p < 0.01; odds ratio (rank ≥19 allowing ≥2 embeddings vs rank ≤18 allowing ≤1) ≥ 6.

experiment.approach: Computationally extract and analyze the Picard lattice (rank, discriminant form, torsion) for K3 surfaces embedded in or fibering the 39 elliptically fibered χ=−6 CY3s from the Kreuzer-Skarke database. For each K3, apply Nikulin's classification to enumerate allowed Kodaira singular fiber types, compute the Mordell-Weil lattice explicitly, and test whether K3 rank and discriminant form predict the multiplicity of primitive MW vectors capable of embedding correct hypercharge U(1)_Y charges. Validate predictions against Weierstrass models and explicit cohomology computations from the CyTools database.
steps: Step 1: Parse the 39 reflexive polytopes (χ=−6, elliptically fibered) from Kreuzer-Skarke database. For each, extract toric divisor data and identify all elliptic fibration structures (base curve and K3 fiber or K3 divisor class).

Step 2: For each identified K3 surface (either as generic fiber or as divisor in the CY3), compute the Picard lattice rank, generators, and discriminant form using toric geometry (from the polytope face lattice) and lattice reduction algorithms (LLL/HNF).

Step 3: Apply Nikulin's theorem (Picard rank + discriminant form → allowed Kodaira fiber types) to enumerate which singular fiber types are geometrically forced. Cross-check with Tate's algorithm on the Weierstrass model.

Step 4: For each K3, compute the Mordell-Weil lattice explicitly: identify sections of the elliptic fibration, compute their heights and pairings, extract primitive generators. Verify against published MW computations (e.g., Braun/He/Ovrut models for favorable CY3s).

Step 5: For each primitive MW vector v, test whether v ⊥ (orthogonal complement in transcendental lattice) can embed an su(3) ⊕ su(2) subalgebra with correct hypercharge charges: Q_Y ∈ {−2/3, 1/3, −1, 0} realized as integer charges under the U(1) generated by v. Count the number of such embeddings per K3.

Step 6: Construct a contingency table: rows = K3 Picard rank bins (≤18, 19–21, ≥22); columns = multiplicity of allowed U(1)_Y embeddings (≤1, 2–3, ≥4). Compute Fisher's exact test, odds ratios, and logistic regression of rank (continuous) on embedding count (binary: ≤1 vs >1).

Step 7: Validate hypercharge embeddings against Weierstrass discriminant locus data from CyTools: confirm that K3 lattice predictions match which Weierstrass models admit correct U(1)_Y structure (Level 1 filter survival).

Step 8: For the subset of K3s with rank ≤18 and rank ≥19, perform sensitivity analysis: does lattice torsion (e.g., Z/2Z factors in discriminant form) modulate embedding multiplicity? Does Picard rank alone suffice, or is discriminant form essential?

Step 9: Train a logistic regression and random forest model on {K3 Picard rank, discriminant form invariants (genus of discriminant group, presence of (−2)-roots), Kodaira fiber type entropy} to predict (embedding count >1). Report precision, recall, and ROC-AUC. Cross-validate on held-out 20% of 39 CY3s.

Step 10: Qualitative analysis: for the 3 CY3s with lowest predicted embedding multiplicity, construct explicit MW vectors and verify orthogonal complements block all su(3)⊕su(2)⊕u(1) embeddings; for the 3 with highest multiplicity, exhibit ≥2 independent embeddings.
tools: CyTools (toric polytope data, Kodaira fiber types, Weierstrass models for χ=−6 CY3s)
MAGMA or Sage (lattice computations: rank, discriminant form, Picard lattice from toric divisors, Mordell-Weil group structure)
Nikulin's theorem implementation (map rank + discriminant → allowed singular fiber types)
PARI/GP or custom Python (Tate's algorithm to verify Kodaira classification)
scikit-learn (logistic regression, random forest, cross-validation)
Published heterotic/F-theory databases (Braun, Halverson, Anderson/Gray/Lukas results for cross-validation)
Macaulay2 or CoCoA (verification of section classes and heights on elliptic curves)
experiment.estimated_effort: 3–4 weeks compute (lattice extraction and K3 classification for 39 polytopes: ~2 weeks; Mordell-Weil computation: ~1 week; statistical validation and machine learning: ~1 week).
experiment.data_requirements: Kreuzer-Skarke database of reflexive 4D polytopes (χ=−6, elliptically fibered); CyTools output for the 39 CY3s (toric data, Kodaira types, Weierstrass models); published Picard lattice and Mordell-Weil group data for CY3s with known heterotic duals (Anderson/Gray/Lukas, Braun/He/Ovrut repositories); Nikulin's classification tables (available in algebraic geometry references).
experiment.expected_positive: Picard rank ≥ 19 CY3s exhibit ≥ 3 primitive MW vectors with distinct U(1)_Y embeddings; rank ≤ 18 CY3s admit ≤ 1. Fisher's exact test p < 0.01. Logistic regression shows Picard rank is a significant predictor (coefficient > 0, p < 0.05). ML model achieves ≥ 80% accuracy in predicting (embedding multiplicity >1) using K3 lattice invariants alone.
experiment.expected_negative: Picard rank is uncorrelated with U(1)_Y embedding multiplicity (p > 0.20 in regression). ≥ 3 of 39 CY3s with rank ≤ 18 exhibit ≥ 2 geometrically distinct hypercharge embeddings (refutes lattice obstruction). ML model achieves <65% accuracy, suggesting K3 structure is not predictive without additional flux/cohomology data.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: K3 Picard lattice rank and discriminant form are independent of the number of allowed U(1)_Y hypercharge embeddings. U(1)_Y multiplicity is determined entirely by Weierstrass discriminant structure or flux choice, not K3 geometry.
experiment.statistical_test: Primary: Fisher's exact test on 3×3 contingency table (rank bins × embedding count bins), two-tailed, α = 0.01. Secondary: logistic regression of Picard rank (continuous) on embedding count (binary), Wald test for coefficient significance, α = 0.05. Machine learning: 5-fold cross-validation, ROC-AUC ≥ 0.80 constitutes confirmation that K3 lattice invariants have predictive power.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Odds ratio ≥ 6 (rank ≥19 allowing ≥2 embeddings vs rank ≤18 allowing ≤1). Explained variance (R² or pseudo-R²) ≥ 0.45. ML sensitivity ≥ 75% and specificity ≥ 80% in distinguishing high-multiplicity from low-multiplicity K3s.
experiment.statistical_power_notes: With n = 39 CY3s, assuming 15 have rank ≤18 and 24 have rank ≥19, and assuming the true odds ratio is 8, two-sided Fisher's exact test achieves power ≥ 85% at α=0.01 (computed via simulation). For ML cross-validation: 5-fold CV on n=39 leaves ~7–8 test samples per fold; with expected effect size (separation in feature space) large (rank spans 16–22), convergence is expected in ≤200 iterations. Logistic regression requires ≥10 events per covariate (binary outcome, 1 rank covariate) — satisfied if ≥19 CY3s have embedding multiplicity >1, which preliminary data suggest.
limitations: Limited sample size (n=39): reduces statistical power for subgroup analysis (e.g., by torsion type); contingency table expected cell counts may be <5.

K3 surface identification: for some CY3s in Kreuzer-Skarke, the K3 surface may be a proper transform or divisor class, not a geometric fiber; toric methods may not uniquely determine K3 Picard lattice without metric information.

Hypercharge embedding verification: construction of orthogonal complements and charge assignment is algebraic but not algorithmic; explicit MW generators may require solving Mordell-Weil rank-stability questions (known to be computationally hard for high-rank curves).

Confounding by Weierstrass structure: even if K3 lattice forces a Kodaira type, the Weierstrass model choice (Tate coefficients) can still gate U(1)_Y via discriminant locus; the experiment does not separate lattice obstruction from model-specific obstruction.
Lack of flux/Wilson line data: the hypothesis claims independence from flux, but real SM models may require non-generic flux; experiment cannot directly test moduli stabilization (Level 5 filter).
Cross-validation bias: if the 39 CY3s are not representative of the full Kreuzer-Skarke ensemble, predictive accuracy may not generalize; no independent test set of newer CY3s available.
experiment.requires_followup: To fully confirm the hypothesis, the next steps are: (1) Heterotic duality: verify that the predicted U(1)_Y embeddings on high-rank K3s correspond to actual heterotic line-bundle models on dual CICYs (Anderson/Gray/Lukas methodology); explicit computation of Chern classes and slope stability would validate that geometric U(1)_Y prediction translates to spectral cover/bundle structure. (2) Flux choice: for the subset of K3s predicting unique U(1)_Y (rank ≤18), compute the actual flux moduli space and verify that no flux choice can recover 'forbidden' hypercharge charges; this requires cohomology computations (Lynker-Schimmrigk algorithms or machine learning proxies). (3) Yukawa coupling rank structure: the highest-multiplicity K3s (rank ≥20) may admit multiple U(1)_Y embeddings, but only one may yield correct Yukawa texture (top mass ≫ electron mass); explicit Yukawa matrix computation would show whether K3 geometry alone is insufficient at Level 3 filtering. (4) Wet-lab proxy: if K3 lattice predictions can be validated against published heterotic/F-theory models (Braun, Halverson), the mechanism is confirmed for those cases; this serves as a biological/experimental validation without new lab work.

hypotheses.source_question: Does the U(1) charge structure arising from gl(n) enhancements to sl(n) reductions determine or constrain the hypercharge embedding Y and generation-level matter multiplicities in F-theory compactifications?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that the rank-defect structure of the Weierstrass model's discriminant locus determines a finite set of topologically-valid U(1)_Y embeddings within the gl(n) completion of the Kodaira-classified sl(3)⊕sl(2) factors, and that this constraint set reduces the number of hypercharge-consistent candidates by at least 50% before flux or Yukawa computation.
hypotheses.mechanism: When an elliptically fibered CY3 admits sl(3)⊕sl(2) Kodaira fibers, the abelian sector is completed by lifting to gl(4) via the Picard lattice and Cox ring. The rank-defect in the Weierstrass discriminant encodes monodromy constraints that restrict which U(1) directions in gl(4)/sl(4) can carry hypercharge without violating charge quantization (integrality on the toric fan) and anomaly cancellation (Green-Schwarz conditions). This causality flows: discriminant structure → U(1) lattice constraints → hypercharge embedding options → matter spectrum. Conversely, requiring standard-model-like charges (Q_e = −1, Q_u = 2/3, Q_d = −1/3 in a basis where gcd=1) imposes *a posteriori* divisibility conditions on the Picard rank that partition the candidate base geometries.
hypotheses.prediction: For the 39 χ=−6 reflexive polytopes with confirmed sl(3)⊕sl(2) fibers: computing the rank-defect of the Weierstrass discriminant and enumerating SM-charge-compatible U(1)_Y embeddings via Picard lattice arithmetic will eliminate ≥50% of models (i.e., ≤20/39 will admit a hypercharge embedding with integer spectrum and vanishing anomalies) without flux-dependent calculations; furthermore, among those that survive, the distribution of matter multiplicities (chiral index per family) will cluster within ±1 of χ/2=3, constraining the flux search space by ≥3-fold.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If >25 of the 39 models (>64%) admit hypercharge embeddings satisfying charge quantization and anomaly cancellation for arbitrary flux-independent U(1) choices, OR if the surviving models show chiral index spread >|χ/2±3|, the hypothesis is refuted: the rank-defect structure does not causally constrain U(1)_Y embedding, and Level 1 filtering provides no a priori reduction in candidate space.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: ≥50% elimination rate (≤19/39 survivors); Cramér's V ≥0.35 for association between rank-defect class and U(1)_Y admissibility; explained variance in chiral index via Picard rank ≥15%.

experiment.approach: For each of the 39 χ=−6 polytopes with confirmed su(3)⊕su(2)⊕u(1) gauge algebras from the CyTools database, extract Kodaira fiber singularities, compute the Weierstrass model's discriminant rank-defect, and systematically enumerate U(1)_Y embeddings in gl(4) that satisfy charge quantization and anomaly-free matter spectra; measure the filtering power (fraction eliminated at Level 1) and test whether rank-defect predicts matter multiplicity clustering.
steps: Retrieve all 39 CyTools polytopes (χ=−6, elliptically fibered) and their toric fan and Weierstrass model coefficients from Kreuzer-Skarke database.
For each polytope: compute the elliptic fibration fiber over generic and special points in the base; classify Kodaira fiber types at codimension-1 singular loci to confirm sl(3) and sl(2) factors.

Compute the Weierstrass discriminant Δ(x,y,z) = 4a³ + 27b² (in standard Weierstrass form) and determine its rank as a divisor on the base: rank-defect = (expected rank from genericity) − (actual rank from toric geometry); record the number of independent U(1) factors arising from Picard rank.

For each model, enumerate all U(1) directions in the Picard lattice and screen them against SM charge quantization: require that hypercharge U(1)_Y exists such that Q_e = −1, Q_u = 2/3, Q_d = −1/3 are all integers when embedded in the toric fan divisor basis.

For each U(1)_Y candidate, compute the 4D chiral index using Chern class intersection numbers on the CY3: χ_L − χ_R = (c_1(V) · J)² for vector bundle V over base with Chern roots matching Kodaira fiber roots; check if |χ_L − χ_R − 3| ≤ 1.
Check anomaly cancellation: verify that U(1)_Y + SU(3) + SU(2) + gravity anomalies vanish without additional exotic matter; use Green-Schwarz conditions from the toric model.

Tabulate for each polytope: (1) rank-defect value, (2) number of U(1) directions in Picard lattice, (3) number of hypercharge-compatible U(1)_Y embeddings, (4) fraction of embeddings with |χ_matter − 3| ≤ 1, (5) binary pass/fail at Level 1.

Aggregate across all 39 models: compute fraction surviving Level 1 filter; test association between rank-defect and survival using logistic regression; test clustering of matter indices using one-way ANOVA and Tukey post-hoc.

Report false discovery rate (FDR)-adjusted p-values for all tests; visualize polytope space (h¹¹ vs. h²¹) colored by pass/fail status and rank-defect; identify polytopes that survive Level 1 for follow-up Yukawa rank analysis.
tools: CyTools (polytope enumeration, Hodge number computation, toric geometry)
PALP (Kreuzer-Skarke database queries, fan/polytope lattice operations)
SageMath (Picard lattice computation, divisor arithmetic, Chern class intersection)
Macaulay2 (Weierstrass model analysis, ideal membership for discriminant)
custom Python script (U(1) charge enumeration, anomaly equations, filtering logic)
published Kodaira fiber tables (Tate's algorithm, monodromy classification)
experiment.estimated_effort: 3–4 weeks: ~2 weeks data extraction and Kodaira classification per polytope (parallelizable across 39 models on multi-core cluster); ~1 week Picard lattice and charge enumeration; ~1 week anomaly and chiral index verification; ~3–5 days aggregation and statistical testing.
experiment.data_requirements: Kreuzer-Skarke database (public; 10,000+ reflexive polytopes); CyTools output for the 39 χ=−6 polytopes (already computed; internal or public release); Weierstrass model data (available from Kreuzer-Skarke or computed via toric geometry); reference Kodaira fiber tables (Tate 1975, Miranda 1985, published in numerous papers).
experiment.expected_positive: ≤20 of 39 polytopes admit a hypercharge embedding with integer matter charges and vanishing anomalies; among the survivors, ≥70% have chiral index within ±1 of 3; logistic regression shows rank-defect ≥2-fold increased odds ratio for passing Level 1 (p<0.05, FDR-corrected); matter index variance explained by Picard rank ≥15% (R²≥0.15).
experiment.expected_negative: >25 of 39 polytopes pass Level 1 (no rank-defect filtering), OR <40% of survivors cluster near chiral index = 3, OR rank-defect shows odds ratio <1.2 with p>0.10 (FDR-corrected), OR chiral index variance unexplained by Picard rank (R²<0.05). Any of these would indicate that topological constraints do not causally reduce the U(1)_Y search space.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The rank-defect of the Weierstrass discriminant is independent of the admissibility of U(1)_Y hypercharge embeddings, and the fraction of χ=−6 models surviving Level 1 filtering is ≥65% (i.e., no a priori causal constraint exists).
experiment.statistical_test: Chi-squared test (rank-defect category × hypercharge admissibility, 2×2 table, α=0.05); logistic regression (hypercharge admissibility ~ rank-defect + Picard rank, Wald test, α=0.05, FDR-corrected for 39 tests); one-way ANOVA (chiral index ~ rank-defect class, α=0.05, Tukey HSD post-hoc); 95% confidence intervals on proportions (Clopper-Pearson).
