experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Odds ratio ≥1.5 for rank-defect ≥2 predicting hypercharge admissibility, with 39 polytopes and ~30% baseline hypercharge admissibility rate, yields 80% power at α=0.05 (two-tailed); R² for chiral index explained by Picard rank ≥0.15 is detectable at 80% power with n=39 and moderate effect size (f²≈0.18); minimum filtering power ≥50% (i.e., ≥19.5 eliminations out of 39) is exact by multinomial test against H₀ of 65% baseline, yielding >90% power.
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Sample size n=39 polytopes is fixed. Baseline admissibility under H₀ ≈65% (25/39); alternative hypothesis posits ≤50% (≤19.5/39). Binomial test: p(X≤19|n=39, p=0.65) ≈0.14 (two-tailed, α=0.05); FDR correction for 39 hypothesis tests using Benjamini-Hochberg procedure (target FDR ≤0.05). Logistic regression with 39 observations and 2–3 predictors (rank-defect, Picard rank, interaction) is well-powered for odds ratio ≥1.5 at α=0.05 (post hoc power ≈0.82). ANOVA for 4–5 rank-defect classes with balanced n≈8 per class: f=0.40 (medium effect) yields power ≈0.75 at α=0.05.
limitations: Sample size limited to 39 polytopes; results may not generalize to χ≠−6 or non-reflexive bases.
Kodaira classification is heuristic and may misidentify fiber types at highly singular loci; will require visual confirmation via explicit discriminant factorization.
U(1) charge enumeration assumes toric geometry is sufficient; non-toric or non-ample anticanonical classes may be missed.
Chiral index from topological Chern classes does not account for flux choice; actual matter multiplicities require flux computation (Level 2 filtering is deferred).
Anomaly cancellation check uses only 4D Green-Schwarz conditions; 6D or swampland constraints not included; may overcount viable models.
No explicit metric or Yukawa rank computation; candidates passing Level 1 may fail Levels 3–6 at high rates.
Replication depends on correct implementation of Kodaira algorithm and Picard lattice arithmetic; cross-validation against published models (e.g., Braun et al., He et al.) recommended.
experiment.requires_followup: Confirmation via explicit Weierstrass model computation and factorization of the discriminant Δ for a subset (5–10) of surviving polytopes, using Macaulay2 or Singular over the toric base. Full validation requires flux choice and Yukawa rank computation (Level 3), which is wet-lab equivalent (F-theory vacua realization); recommend subsequent study on top 10 polytopes passing Level 1.

hypotheses.source_question: Do metastable potentials in string-theory-derived SM vacua systematically exhibit potential barriers whose heights and widths are constrained by the discrete symmetries and moduli-stabilization geometry, and can this constraint be inverted to filter candidate vacua?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that the height and width of potential barriers in SM-like scalar directions are causally determined by the Kähler geometry and moduli-stabilization scheme of the parent CY3, such that polytopes with χ = −6 and certain Kodaira fiber types systematically produce sub-Planckian barriers that render nominally SM-like vacua cosmologically unstable on timescales less than 10^10 yr, thereby filtering the candidate space by more than 80% when barrier robustness is included as a Level 5.5 criterion.
hypotheses.mechanism: The effective scalar potential V_eff for SM directions is determined by V = |∂W/∂φ_i|² − 3|W|², where W encodes the superpotential structure and the Kähler metric g_ij̄ shapes the geometry of scalar directions. For elliptic fibrations over toric bases, the Kodaira fiber classification constrains the moduli-stabilization scales (m_stab ∝ exp(−aV) in KKLT/LVS). A CY3 with χ = −6 paired with specific Kodaira types produces Kähler metrics with restricted rank in the mixed Higgs-moduli sector, forcing second derivatives at saddle points to be small. This causes barriers to be broad and shallow, with height V_barrier much less than m_stab. Lower barriers increase tunneling rates (Γ ∝ exp(−S_B)); higher rates cause vacuum decay on cosmologically unviable timescales. Thus geometry causally determines barrier structure, and barrier structure causally selects viable vacua.
hypotheses.prediction: Among the 39 χ = −6 elliptically fibered CY3 threefolds: at least 70% will exhibit potential barriers in the SM scalar sector with heights V_barrier less than 10^10 GeV when computed via numerical Kähler geometry plus effective superpotential; for those 70%, the barrier robustness ratio (V_barrier divided by m_stab) will be less than 0.1, implying tunneling timescales less than 10^10 yr; the remaining at most 30% with V_barrier greater than 10^10 GeV and robustness greater than 0.1 will be enriched by more than 75% in polytopes exhibiting non-generic Kodaira fiber types such as higher-rank singular fibers or elevated Picard rank.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: The hypothesis is falsified if: more than 50% of the 39 polytopes exhibit V_barrier greater than 10^10 GeV via the Kähler plus superpotential computation; OR barrier robustness shows no statistically significant correlation (Spearman rho greater than 0.35 or p greater than 0.05 with Bonferroni correction for n=39) with Kodaira fiber type, χ, or Hodge numbers; OR the set of robust vacua (barrier robustness greater than 0.1) is uniformly distributed across all Kodaira types and shows less than 40% enrichment in high-rank fiber configurations.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Spearman rank correlation rho greater than 0.35 between barrier robustness and Kodaira fiber class at p less than 0.05 with Bonferroni correction for n=39; greater than 2-fold enrichment of robust vacua in high-rank Kodaira fiber polytopes versus generic fibers; V_barrier range spanning at least 5 orders of magnitude (10^7 to 10^12 GeV) across the 39-polytope set.

experiment.approach: For each of the 39 χ = −6 reflexive polytopes: extract toric data and compute the elliptic fibration; use Donaldson-type algorithms or machine-learned Kähler metric approximations to construct the Kähler metric restricted to the SM scalar sector; compute the effective superpotential W by integrating flux and non-perturbative contributions using topological data and anomalous U(1) constraints; numerically solve for critical points of V_eff to locate vacua and saddle points; extract barrier heights and compute the moduli-stabilization scale m_stab from the Kähler volume and Kodaira discriminant; form the barrier robustness ratio and cross-tabulate against Kodaira fiber type and Hodge numbers; apply correlation analysis to assess whether geometry determines barrier structure.
steps: Download the 39 χ = −6 polytopes from the Kreuzer-Skarke database and extract toric data including vertices, facets, and Hodge numbers h11 and h21.
For each polytope, compute the Kodaira fiber classification using toric tools and record fiber types and multiplicities.
Construct the Kähler metric tensor on the SM scalar-field sector using machine-learned metric approximations trained on known CICYs and validated against published examples.
Parameterize the superpotential W from first principles including w0 (moduli stabilization), non-perturbative exponential terms, and flux-instanton contributions using anomalous U(1) constraints.
Compute the effective potential V_eff(φ_Higgs, φ_moduli) = e^K |D_iW|² − 3|W|² by taking covariant derivatives with respect to Kähler-metric-weighted fields.
Numerically locate all critical points (vacua and saddle points) of V_eff using gradient-descent and Hessian analysis with multiple random initializations.
For each critical point, compute Hessian eigenvalues to identify saddle points and extract barrier height V_barrier = V(saddle) − V(nearest minimum).
Determine m_stab from the Kähler volume in units of M_Pl cubed, yielding values in the range 10^7 to 10^12 GeV.

Calculate barrier robustness R = V_barrier divided by m_stab for each polytope and partition candidates into three classes: robust (R greater than 0.1), marginal (0.01 less than R less than 0.1), and fragile (R less than 0.01).
Cross-tabulate barrier heights and robustness ratios against Kodaira fiber type, χ, h11, h21, and Picard rank using Spearman rank correlation and logistic regression.
Compute tunneling timescale tau for fragile vacua using the WKB formula and assess which polytopes are ruled out by tau less than 10^10 yr constraint.
Identify polytopes in the robust class and examine whether their Kodaira fiber configurations share common topological features not present in fragile polytopes.
tools: PALP for Kreuzer-Skarke database interface and Hodge number computation
Singular or Macaulay2 for toric geometry and discriminant-locus calculation
Machine-learned CY-metric package based on He-Lukas bundle stability model or custom neural network trained on approximately 10000 CICYs
SageMath and Python libraries including NumPy, SciPy, and JAX for Kähler tensor algebra and numerical optimization
Julia or C++ with autodiff libraries for high-precision Hessian computation and critical-point location
R and Python with scikit-learn and statsmodels for correlation analysis, logistic regression, and enrichment testing
CyTools from MIT for elliptic fibration analysis and secondary polytope computation
experiment.estimated_effort: 3 to 4 months full-time compute plus analysis, parallelizable over the 39 polytopes with each barrier computation requiring 1 to 10 GPU-hours depending on metric approximation quality.
experiment.data_requirements: Kreuzer-Skarke database with polytope and Hodge data; published Kähler metrics for favorable CICYs; anomalous U(1) charges from heterotic and F-theory literature; superpotential structures from Braun, Ovrut, Cvetic, and Halverson papers; machine-learning training data on bundle stability and metric eigenvalues from approximately 10000 to 100000 examples.
experiment.expected_positive: Computation yields V_barrier spanning 10^7 to 10^12 GeV across the 39 polytopes, with at least 70% exhibiting V_barrier less than 10^10 GeV and barrier robustness R less than 0.1; Spearman rho between R and Kodaira fiber type greater than 0.35 with p less than 0.001 after Bonferroni correction; robust polytopes show at least 75% enrichment in high-rank Kodaira fiber types; tunneling timescales for fragile vacua are less than 10^10 yr.
experiment.expected_negative: Barrier heights cluster tightly with no correlation to Kodaira type or Hodge numbers; barrier robustness R is uniformly distributed across polytopes and fiber types with Spearman rho less than 0.2 and p greater than 0.05; fragile and robust vacua show less than 40% enrichment differences in Kodaira configurations; tunneling timescales are predominantly greater than 10^11 yr across all polytopes.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H0: The height and width of potential barriers in SM scalar directions are independent of the Kähler geometry, Kodaira fiber type, and moduli-stabilization scheme. Formally: V_barrier and barrier robustness R are uncorrelated with Kodaira fiber class, Hodge numbers, Picard rank, and χ, with Spearman rho less than 0.2 and p greater than 0.05 with Bonferroni correction.
experiment.statistical_test: Spearman rank correlation (two-sided) between barrier robustness and Kodaira fiber type; Kendall tau for robustness versus Hodge-number pairs; logistic regression with Wald test for regression coefficients; hypergeometric test for enrichment of robust polytopes in high-rank-fiber class; Fisher exact test for 2x2 contingency tables. Family-wise alpha = 0.05 with Bonferroni correction across 8 primary tests yields per-test alpha approximately 0.006.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Spearman rank correlation rho greater than 0.35 between barrier robustness and Kodaira fiber type achievable with n=39 at 80% power and alpha=0.01; greater than 2-fold enrichment of robust polytopes in high-rank Kodaira fibers versus generic at p less than 0.05; V_barrier range greater than 5 orders of magnitude with coefficient of variation greater than 1.5.
experiment.statistical_power_notes: With n=39 polytopes, two-sided Spearman correlation alpha=0.01, assumed rho_true=0.40, power=80%: critical r_s approximately 0.38 is achievable. Logistic regression with 4 predictors requires approximately 10 to 20 per group (robust versus fragile), achievable with expected approximately 12 robust and approximately 27 fragile. Enrichment test (Fisher exact, 2x2 table) with expected cell counts greater than 5 is well-powered. Computational convergence criterion: Hessian eigenvalue computation converges when the Frobenius norm of H(iteration k) minus H(iteration k-1) is less than 10^-6; barrier height stable when estimates differ less than 1% across three independent numerical solves.
limitations: Machine-learned Kähler metrics introduce approximation error; validation against known examples (few dozen) limits confidence in extrapolation to all 39 polytopes.
Superpotential parameterization relies on existing literature and may miss exotic non-perturbative terms or flux contributions not yet catalogued.
Tunneling timescale calculation uses simplified WKB formula; full quantum gravitational effects in curved spacetime are not included.
The 39-polytope sample is small for detecting correlations with multiple confounders; unmeasured topological invariants may act as hidden confounders.
Only elliptically fibered polytopes are examined; the universality of barrier constraints across other CY3 geometries remains open.
experiment.requires_followup: Direct Kähler metric computation via Donaldson-type numerics for 3 to 5 polytopes to cross-validate machine-learned metric approximations and confirm barrier heights to within 10% accuracy. Heterotic line-bundle model construction for 1 to 2 high-robustness polytopes to verify explicit superpotential structures and moduli-stabilization scales. Flux-scanning over 100 to 1000 flux sectors for at least one polytope to assess robustness of barrier predictions to flux-choice variation. These wet-lab-equivalent follow-ups would be needed to elevate Level 5.5 barrier criterion into a published filtering level.

hypotheses.source_question: Do M2 instanton effects, through their contributions to the superpotential and Yukawa sector, provide a necessary and sufficient mechanism for generating the observed hierarchical fermion mass structure in SM vacua derived from F-theory, and can their exponential suppression factors be calibrated to reproduce fermion mass ratios without additional fine-tuning?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that M2 instanton contributions to the superpotential, parametrized by quantized wrapping degrees on elliptic divisors and exponential suppression factors exp(−S_inst), are a necessary mechanism for generating the observed hierarchical fermion mass texture in F-theory SM vacua, and that the distribution of M2 instanton loci uniquely selects models reproducing empirical CKM mixing angles without additional fine-tuning of moduli.
hypotheses.mechanism: M2 instantons wrapping rational curves on elliptic divisors contribute terms to the superpotential with coefficients suppressed by exp(−S_inst(moduli)), where S_inst scales with the curve genus and wrapping degree. These contributions act as selective rank-deficiency generators in the Yukawa matrix: low-genus (high-amplitude) M2 instantons create off-diagonal mass-matrix entries that establish hierarchy, while high-genus (exponentially suppressed) terms preserve texture zeros required for CKM unitary triangles. Mechanistic direction: M2 instanton geometry causes superpotential term selection, which causes Yukawa matrix rank structure, which causes fermion mass hierarchy. Without M2 instantons, tree-level Yukawa couplings alone produce either rank-full matrices (no hierarchy) or accidental texture zeros (inconsistent with CKM data).
hypotheses.prediction: For a sample of N greater than or equal to 20 F-theory models with elliptically fibered CY3s (chi equals negative 6, h11 greater than or equal to 15), the set of M2 instantons with suppression factor |exp(−S_inst)| greater than 10 to the negative 3 will generate at least 60 percent of the Yukawa matrix entries required to reproduce measured fermion mass ratios and CKM unitarity-triangle angle within 2 degrees of the experimental measurement. Equivalently, models in which M2 instanton contributions are computationally set to zero will fail to match empirical fermion masses.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If, after enumerating all M2 instantons and constructing the Yukawa matrix as a linear superposition of tree-level and M2-instanton-generated terms, the resulting mass eigenvalues deviate from measured values by more than 5-fold, OR if the required M2 instanton suppression factors differ from the moduli-dependent prediction by more than one order of magnitude, then M2 instantons are not sufficient. Alternatively, if more than 70 percent of level-0 candidates produce acceptable fermion mass hierarchies using only tree-level Yukawa couplings without M2 instanton input, then M2 instantons are not necessary.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Explained variance in fermion mass matrix greater than 60 percent (R squared greater than 0.60) attributable to M2 instanton contributions. In terms of statistical discrimination: at least 14 of 20 models must pass the Yukawa filter when M2 instantons are included, versus 3 or fewer of 20 when M2 contributions are zeroed.

experiment.approach: Computationally enumerate M2 instantons on elliptic divisors from public F-theory model databases, calculate superpotential coefficients from instanton geometry, construct Yukawa matrices as superpositions of tree-level and M2-instanton-generated terms, and screen against empirical fermion masses and CKM data.
steps: Extract 20-30 F-theory models with chi equals negative 6 and elliptic fibrations from CYTools database; confirm h11 greater than or equal to 15.
For each model, compute the toric fan and divisor class group of the elliptic surface; identify rational curves and elliptic curves in the elliptic divisor fiber.
Use toric geometry to enumerate M2 instanton wrapped states: for each curve, compute the wrapping degree d, genus g, and intersection multiplicity with the anticanonical divisor.
For each M2 instanton configuration, compute the action S_inst using the Kahler form and moduli-dependent volume integrals; calculate suppression factor exp(−S_inst) as a function of Kahler moduli.
Enumerate superpotential terms generated by M2 instantons: map wrapped curves to monomials in the coordinate ring using the toric dictionary.
For each model, assume a generic moduli snapshot (tau_i in range [1,10]); construct the Yukawa matrix Y_ij equals Y_tree plus sum over A of c_A times Y_A to the power of M2.
Diagonalize Y_ij; extract eigenvalues m_1, m_2, m_3 and compare to measured masses and CKM angles.
Quantify fit quality using chi-squared; models pass Level 3 filter if chi-squared less than 10.
Repeat with M2 instanton contributions zeroed (Y_ij equals Y_tree only); count how many models still pass Level 3 filter.
Perform sensitivity analysis: for each passing model, perturb M2 instanton suppression factors by plus-or-minus 1 order of magnitude.
Cross-validate texture-zero predictions: identify which entries of Y_ij are predicted zero by M2 instanton geometry; check whether these match heterotic spectral cover predictions.
Perform two-proportion binomial test: H0 is p_M2 equals p_tree; H1 is p_M2 greater than p_tree.
tools: CYTools for polytope database queries and toric divisor computation
Cvetic-Halverson F-theory dataset
SageMath Polytopes module for toric geometry
Palp and Polymake for fan-divisor computations
TropicalGeometry.jl for rational curve enumeration
Custom Python code for Kahler metric computation, instanton action calculation, and Yukawa matrix assembly
scipy.optimize.least_squares for chi-squared minimization
scipy.stats.binom_test for statistical testing
experiment.estimated_effort: 8-12 weeks (4 weeks toric divisor enumeration, 3 weeks instanton action and Yukawa assembly, 2 weeks mass matrix fitting, 1 week cross-validation, 1-2 weeks documentation). Estimated 200-500 GPU-core-hours for toric geometry bottleneck.
experiment.data_requirements: Public CYTools database with chi equals negative 6, elliptic fibrations, h11 greater than or equal to 15; Cvetic-Halverson F-theory model repository; empirical fermion masses and CKM parameters from PDG 2023. Storage approximately 10 GB.
experiment.expected_positive: For at least 14 of 20 models, M2 instanton contributions reproduce measured fermion mass ratios and CKM angles within plus-or-minus 30 percent, with texture-zero positions matching spectral-cover predictions. Chi-squared less than 10 with M2 terms included; chi-squared greater than 100 when zeroed.
experiment.expected_negative: Fewer than 3 of 20 models pass Level 3 Yukawa filter even with M2 instantons included, or required suppression factors deviate from predictions by more than 2 orders of magnitude. Alternatively, more than 70 percent of models fit fermion masses using tree-level terms alone with no significant improvement from M2 terms.
experiment.null_hypothesis: The distribution of M2 instanton suppression factors does not preferentially generate Yukawa matrix entries that improve the fit to empirical fermion masses and CKM parameters compared to tree-level terms alone. Formally: the fraction of models passing Level 3 filtering with M2 instantons is equal to or less than the fraction passing with tree-level terms only: p_M2 less than or equal to p_tree.
experiment.statistical_test: Two-proportion binomial test (exact, two-tailed) comparing fraction of models passing Level 3 filter with M2 instantons versus without; alpha equals 0.05, target power equals 0.80 for detecting relative risk of 3 (p_tree approximately 0.15, p_M2 approximately 0.45 under alternative). For 20 models, n equals 20 per arm.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Relative risk at least 2.5: if 15 percent of models pass Level 3 with tree-level Yukawa only, M2 instantons must boost this to at least 37.5 percent. Alternatively, explained variance R squared in fermion mass eigenvalues attributable to M2 instantons at least 0.40.
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Assumed effect: under H1, M2 instantons increase proportion of Level-3-passing models from p0 equals 0.15 to p1 equals 0.45 (RR equals 3.0). With n equals 20 per arm, binomial test at alpha equals 0.05 achieves power approximately 0.78-0.82. Expansion to n equals 30 per arm increases power to approximately 0.90. For continuous outcomes, assume effect size Cohen f squared approximately 0.22; ANCOVA requires n approximately 28 per group for power equals 0.80.
limitations: Moduli-dependent instanton action requires integration over Kahler metrics dependent on unknown Kahler moduli. Experiment assumes generic snapshot; true moduli stabilization may alter suppression factors by approximately 1 order of magnitude.
M2 instanton enumeration relies on toric geometry; non-toric or singular bases may harbor additional instantons not captured by standard methods, introducing potential underestimation.
Yukawa couplings approximated via toric monomials without explicit metric integrals, introducing model error approximately 10-30 percent.
Cross-validation against heterotic spectral cover models is indirect; heterotic duality maps are conjectural for many models.
CKM angle extraction assumes specific fermion basis convention; choice of up-type versus down-type Yukawa matrix may introduce plus-or-minus 5 degree ambiguity.
No explicit string compactification metric computed; all volumes and actions approximated using toric combinatorics, potentially shifting instanton exponents by 10-20 percent.
experiment.requires_followup: If computational experiment identifies M2 instanton configurations as critical discriminators, future work should: (1) verify predictions by computing explicit metrics on resolved CY3s for selected models (heterotic dual if available); (2) cross-check instanton actions using alternative methods (mirror symmetry, Gromov-Witten invariants); (3) perform string landscape scans to determine whether M2-instanton-selected models cluster in moduli space (suggesting genuine selection, not chance correlation). No wet-lab confirmation needed for this theory-level hypothesis.

hypotheses.source_question: Does the existence of an exact filling for a contact 3-manifold impose topological or geometric obstructions on the moduli space of strong fillings, and can these obstructions be used to discriminate SM-compatible Calabi-Yau geometries from non-physical vacua?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that the existence of an exact Liouville filling for the generic elliptic fiber of a CY3 threefold causally restricts the moduli space of strong fillings in a way that discriminates SM-viable vacua: specifically, exactness conditions on the contact 3-manifold reduce the dimensionality of the allowable flux lattice by eliminating non-quantizable directions, thereby increasing the probability that a model survives Yukawa rank and proton-decay filter tests by at least 3-fold.
hypotheses.mechanism: Exact fillings require a Liouville vector field whose flow generates a contact structure via a primitive 1-form satisfying d(λ ∧ dλ) = 0. This rigidity constraint propagates to the elliptic fibration: it forces monodromy representations with restricted conjugacy classes in Sp(2g, ℤ) (where g is the genus of the spectral curve). Restricted monodromy eliminates certain Kodaira fiber degeneration patterns, which in turn limits admissible flux quantum numbers. Non-exact strong fillings tolerate broader monodromy freedom, leading to larger flux lattices and higher likelihood of incompatible chirality indices or Yukawa textures. The causal direction is: exactness constraints → reduced monodromy freedom → reduced flux space → increased filter survival rate.
hypotheses.prediction: Among the 39 χ = -6 elliptically fibered CY3s, models satisfying exact Liouville filling criteria (operationalized via Hamiltonian volume growth rate ≤ 2 and contact homology rank drop ≥ 30% between regular and singular fibers) will show ≥3-fold higher empirical survival rates through combined Yukawa-rank and proton-decay filters compared to models failing exactness tests. Quantitatively: if non-exact models show ~5% survival (baseline), exact-filling models should show ≥15% survival when subjected to the same filter pipeline.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If, after controlling for Hodge numbers and polytope face count, the Spearman rank correlation between exactness score (0–1 based on Liouville vector field strength and contact homology diagnostics) and empirical filter-survival rate (proportion advancing past Levels 2–4: hypercharge embedding, chirality-flux match, Yukawa rank) is ρ < 0.15 with p > 0.20 (n=39), the hypothesis is refuted. Alternatively, if models with high exactness scores fail proton-decay and Yukawa tests at the same rate as low-exactness models (chi-squared contingency test, p > 0.05), the proposed causal mechanism is falsified.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Spearman ρ ≥ 0.40 (moderate positive correlation, achievable with n=39 at 80% power given typical effect sizes in geometric filter studies); Cohen's h ≥ 0.5 for contingency table (medium effect, comparing survival proportions ~5% vs. ≥15%); at least one model class (e.g., polytopes with h¹¹ > 15) must show ≥2.5× improvement in filter-passage rate when exactness-filtered.

experiment.approach: For each of the 39 χ = -6 elliptically fibered reflexive polytopes from Kreuzer-Skarke, extract Hodge diamond and elliptic fibration data, compute topological invariants of the generic elliptic fiber treated as a contact 3-manifold, calculate an exactness score via Hamiltonian volume growth and contact homology diagnostics, then correlate exactness scores with empirical survival through known filter pipelines (using published outcomes from Anderson/Gray, Braun/He/Ovrut, and Cvetic/Halverson studies).
steps: Step 1: Retrieve all 39 χ = -6 polytopes and their toric data from Kreuzer-Skarke database; verify elliptic fibration structure and extract discriminant locus factorization.
Step 2: For each polytope, compute the generic elliptic fiber as a toric surface; construct its mirror (Dolgachev mirror or spectral cover dual) to obtain contact 3-manifold structure.
Step 3: Compute Chern class c₁, c₂, and monodromy genus g from spectral cover discriminant; extract monodromy conjugacy class in Sp(2g, ℤ) using eigenvalues of monodromy matrix.

Step 4: Calculate Hamiltonian volume growth rate: for the associated Liouville domain (the elliptic surface minus singular fibers), compute λ_max = largest eigenvalue of monodromy; if λ_max ≤ 2 flag as 'exact-compatible'.

Step 5: For each polytope, compute Seiberg-Witten invariants or use obstruction bundle rank as a proxy for contact homology rank; specifically, measure the drop in Floer homology dimension from generic to singular locus as a contact rigidity score (0–1, normalized by expected rank for χ = -6).
Step 6: Define exactness score E = (0.6 × λ_max compliance) + (0.4 × contact homology drop); threshold E ≥ 0.65 as 'exact-admitting'.

Step 7: Cross-reference each polytope with published filter results from Anderson/Gray CICYs heterotic scans and Braun/He/Ovrut SU(5) → SM breaking studies; extract binary outcome (survives Levels 2–4 yes/no) for each model.

Step 8: Compute Spearman rank correlation ρ between exactness score E and filter-survival outcome; calculate contingency table (2×2: high E vs. low E; survives vs. fails) and perform chi-squared test.
Step 9: Stratify by Hodge number class (h¹¹ < 15, 15 ≤ h¹¹ ≤ 20, h¹¹ > 20) and repeat correlation within each stratum to control for confounds.

Step 10: Train a logistic regression model predicting survival (yes/no) from topological features (c₁, c₂, monodromy genus, λ_max, contact rank drop); report AUC and feature importance; compare to baseline (Hodge numbers alone).
tools: CyTools (Python; polytope and Hodge diamond extraction)
SageMath / Macaulay2 (toric variety and spectral curve computations)
SymPy + NumPy (monodromy matrix eigenvalue decomposition)
published datasets: Kreuzer-Skarke database (117,651 polytopes), Anderson/Gray heterotic bundle scan (~10⁸ line bundles), Braun/He/Ovrut SU(5) model filters (O(10⁵) candidates, O(100) survivors)
Pandas + SciPy (correlation analysis, contingency tables)
scikit-learn (logistic regression, AUC computation)
custom Python module for contact homology obstruction rank via Chern-class algebra
experiment.estimated_effort: 3–4 weeks: 1 week data aggregation + cross-referencing with published filters; 1.5 weeks monodromy and contact homology computations (embarrassingly parallel, ~4 hr per polytope on single core); 0.5 weeks statistical analysis and logistic regression training; 1 week sensitivity checks and stratified reanalysis.
experiment.data_requirements: Kreuzer-Skarke database (public, ~500 MB), CyTools output for 39 polytopes (generated in-house or via public CyTools server), published filter outcome tables from Anderson, Braun, Cvetic (available in supplementary materials of cited papers or upon request); no proprietary data required.
experiment.expected_positive: Spearman ρ ≥ 0.40 between exactness score and filter-survival rate (p < 0.05, one-tailed); chi-squared test on contingency table shows p < 0.05 with effect size Cohen's h ≥ 0.5; logistic regression AUC ≥ 0.72 (vs. Hodge-only baseline ~0.58); at least one Hodge-number stratum shows ≥2.5× survival improvement in high-exactness group.
experiment.expected_negative: Spearman ρ < 0.15 (p > 0.20); chi-squared p > 0.05; logistic regression AUC < 0.62; survival rates are statistically indistinguishable between high- and low-exactness groups across all strata.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The exactness score (derived from monodromy genus, Hamiltonian volume growth, and contact homology rank) is independent of filter-survival outcome. Survival through Yukawa-rank and proton-decay tests is determined by Hodge numbers and Kodaira fiber types alone, with no additional predictive power from contact-geometric exactness conditions.
experiment.statistical_test: Primary: Spearman rank correlation ρ, two-tailed, α = 0.05. Secondary: chi-squared test of independence on 2×2 contingency table (high/low exactness vs. survives/fails), α = 0.05. Tertiary: logistic regression with 10-fold cross-validation, reporting AUC ± SE and feature importance via permutation analysis. Multiple-comparison correction: Bonferroni-adjust for stratified analyses (if 3 Hodge strata, set α_adj = 0.05/3 ≈ 0.017 per test).
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Spearman ρ = 0.40 detectable at 80% power with n = 39 (one-tailed). Contingency chi-squared with effect size h = 0.5 (corresponding to survival rates of 5% vs. 15%, or similar magnitude difference) detectable at 80% power with n ≥ 35. Logistic regression with 8 features requires n ≥ 40 for stable parameter estimates (rules of thumb: 15–20 observations per predictor); n = 39 is marginal but acceptable given pilot nature.
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Sample size n = 39 (fixed; all χ = -6 elliptically fibered polytopes in K-S database). Two-tailed Spearman correlation α = 0.05, desired power 80%: for ρ = 0.40, n = 39 achieves ~82% power (using G*Power). Chi-squared test with h = 0.5, α = 0.05, power 80%: requires n ≥ 35, so n = 39 adequate. Logistic regression: 8 candidate features, 10-fold CV mitigates small-n bias. If correlation ρ < 0.40, study is underpowered; post-hoc power analysis will quantify this. Conservative approach: report effect size + 95% CI rather than relying on p-values alone.
limitations: Small sample size (n = 39) limits power to detect small-to-medium effect sizes; ρ < 0.35 may be missed.
Published filter outcomes (from Anderson, Braun, Cvetic studies) use different flux bases and Yukawa criteria; heterogeneity in filter definition may attenuate observed correlations.

Exactness score relies on monodromy eigenvalue and contact homology rank, both computed using toric approximations; full Floer or contact homology computation is computationally intractable for many polytopes.

Causal claim (exactness → filter survival) relies on cross-sectional correlation; confounding by unmeasured polytope properties (e.g., discriminant singularity type, Picard lattice rank) possible. Stratification by Hodge number provides partial control.
Generic fiber contact structure is defined up to diffeomorphism; exactness in different trivializations or gradings may yield different conclusions. Results may not generalize beyond χ = -6 subclass.
No explicit Yukawa rank or chirality computation; correlation with published filter outcomes assumes those publications applied filters consistently and reproducibly.
experiment.requires_followup: If hypothesis is confirmed computationally (ρ ≥ 0.40, p < 0.05), follow-up wet-lab analogue: (1) Select a high-exactness-score polytope (e.g., GL=12/D₆) and one low-exactness comparator. (2) Compute explicit Weierstrass model, discriminant locus, and monodromy matrices. (3) Use heterotic spectral cover construction (Braun/He methodology) or F-theory base construction (Cvetic/Halverson) to realize both models explicitly. (4) Perform ab initio Yukawa matrix rank computation via Chern-class intersections on the spectral cover or via global sections of line bundles. (5) Check proton-decay amplitude and discrete symmetry survival. (6) Correlate results with computational exactness prediction to validate the causal mechanism. This wet-lab follow-up would be 6–12 months (published models exist; primary effort is algebraic geometry / intersection theory computation).

hypotheses.source_question: For log Calabi-Yau varieties arising in F-theory compactifications with singular fibers, does the structure of the log canonical bundle K_X(D) constrain the possible gauge algebras and chiral matter spectra via topological discriminants, without explicit resolution or metric computation?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that the log canonical bundle K_X(D) of an elliptically fibered Calabi-Yau threefold X, where D encodes the divisor of singular Kodaira fibers, causally constrains the chirality index and Yukawa coupling rank structure via intersection-theoretic invariants, such that topological filtering (intersection numbers on the log variety) eliminates ≥50% of non-SM-like candidates without explicit resolution or flux computation.
hypotheses.mechanism: Singular Kodaira fibers (I₁, II, III, …, IV*) generate a logarithmic divisor D whose log-discrepancies and intersection lattice encode the monodromy action on the discriminant locus. This monodromy directly generates the matter multiplicities and chirality indices via the action on the elliptic curve's cohomology. The log canonical bundle K_X(D) trivializes on the log variety by definition, but its restriction to the singular locus D encodes the gauge-theoretic data: Chern classes of K_X(D)|_D compute the net chirality (genus formula) and Yukawa rank (via vanishing theorems on log resolutions). Thus: singular fiber configuration → log discriminant divisor → intersection lattice → chirality & Yukawa rank (causal chain: geometry → topology → physics).
hypotheses.prediction: For the 39 χ = −6 elliptically fibered CY3 models from Kreuzer-Skarke: intersection-number-based topological predictor (using only Kodaira fiber types, base surface genus, and log-discrepancy weights) will correctly identify ≥50% of models that have at least 3 chiral generations AND Yukawa rank ≥ 5 (necessary for realistic SM Yukawa textures), matching explicit flux-based results from Cvetic/Halverson benchmarks, with ≥0.7 precision and recall ≥0.6 on a holdout set of 8 models.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If the intersection-theoretic topological predictor achieves <40% sensitivity (fails to identify models that explicit flux computation confirms have 3 chiralities AND Yukawa rank ≥5) OR <0.5 precision (predicts SM-like but computation shows inadequate chirality/rank), the hypothesis is refuted: it would demonstrate that log-geometric invariants alone are insufficient and that explicit resolution + flux computation is mandatory.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Topological predictor Precision ≥0.7, Recall ≥0.6, and F₁-score ≥0.65 on held-out 8/39 models; sensitivity (true positive rate for SM-compatible models) ≥50%; >5-fold reduction in computational cost vs. full flux scan (from O(10⁵) point evaluations per model to O(10²) intersection calculations).

experiment.approach: Extract the singular locus (Kodaira fiber types) from CyTools database for all 39 χ = −6 models; formalize each as a log-discrepancy divisor D. Compute intersection numbers I(K_X(D), curves_in_D) and Chern class c₂(K_X(D)|_D). Train a logistic/random forest classifier on 31 models (using topological features only) to predict SM-compatibility (3 chiralities + Yukawa rank ≥5), validated against explicit Cvetic/Halverson flux results. Test on holdout 8 models and compare accuracy vs. null (random guessing: ~30% precision).
steps: Step 1: Extract from CyTools and F-theory databases (Weierstrass + CICY models) the 39 χ=−6 elliptically fibered CY3 threefolds; record base surface, fiber genus, Picard lattice.
Step 2: For each model, extract Kodaira singular fiber types (I₁, II, III, IV, I₀*, I₁*, II*, III*, IV*) from the discriminant divisor Δ of the Weierstrass equation; encode as divisor D.
Step 3: Compute log-discrepancy vector (a_i for each fiber component) using monodromy weight formula: a_i = 1 − (m_i / m_total) where m_i is the multiplicity in the discriminant.
Step 4: Calculate intersection matrix I_ij = (C_i · C_j)_base for rational curves in the resolved fiber; compute self-intersections and genus via genus formula g = 1 + (K_base + D) · C / 2.
Step 5: Compute Chern classes: c₁(K_X(D)) = 0 (log-CY condition); c₂(K_X(D)|_D) via adjunction and restriction formulas; intersection pairing c₂ · [D].

Step 6: Extract topological features for each model: (i) total number of singular fibers, (ii) distribution of Kodaira types, (iii) log-discrepancy spectrum, (iv) base Hodge numbers h¹¹(base), h²¹(base), (v) Picard rank ρ, (vi) intersection numbers on exceptional divisors.

Step 7: Retrieve ground-truth labels from literature: for each model, identify which have 3 chiral generations (from explicit chirality index = χ/2 ± flux/torsion analysis) AND Yukawa coupling rank ≥5 (from explicit flux scanning or heterotic dual [Braun/He/Ovrut results]). If unavailable, compute chirality index directly using Chern class formula: net_chirality = ∫ c_top(V_matter) ∧ ω_base where V_matter is the M-theory uplift bundle.
Step 8: Partition 39 models: 31 training, 8 holdout test. Split training further: 24 fit, 7 validation (for early stopping).
Step 9: Train binary classifier (logistic regression, random forest, or gradient boosting) on training set using topological features alone; target = 1 if (χ/2 = 3 AND Yukawa rank ≥5), 0 otherwise.
Step 10: Evaluate on validation set; report precision, recall, F₁-score; tune hyperparameters to maximize F₁ (balance false positives vs. false negatives in SM filtering context).
Step 11: Final test on holdout 8 models; report confusion matrix and ROC-AUC.
Step 12: Compute feature importance (SHAP or permutation importance) to identify which topological invariants are most predictive of SM-compatibility.

Step 13: Estimate computational cost: count number of intersection calculations (O(ρ²) per model, ρ ≤ 20) vs. explicit flux enumeration (O(10³–10⁵) point evaluations per model); report speedup factor.

Step 14: For 3–4 most promising models (high topological score + labeled as SM-like in literature), perform *validation* via explicit flux scanning (Monte Carlo or systematic grid in moduli space) to confirm chirality & Yukawa rank match topological prediction.
tools: CyTools (Sage package for polytope/Weierstrass model analysis; publicly available)
PALP (lattice polytope enumeration; standard tool in F-theory community)
Macaulay2 or CoCoA (intersection number computation on toric varieties)
Python scikit-learn (classification, feature importance)
F-theory/heterotic duality tables from arXiv:1701.05202 (Cvetic/Halverson benchmark models)
SageMath or Magma for Chern class and genus formula automation
CY database (arXiv:1306.6052, Kreuzer-Skarke polytope database)
flux-enumeration code (custom Python; integrate models from arXiv:1905.02831 if available)
experiment.estimated_effort: 3–4 weeks (2 weeks data extraction & topological feature computation; 1 week classifier training & validation; 1 week flux validation on subset; incremental).
experiment.data_requirements: CyTools-compatible Weierstrass models for 39 polytopes (already in public database); Cvetic/Halverson benchmark results (arXiv:1701.05202 and related; publicly available tables); Hodge numbers & Picard lattice data from Kreuzer-Skarke (public).
experiment.expected_positive: Topological classifier achieves Precision ≥0.7, Recall ≥0.6, F₁ ≥0.65 on holdout 8 models; feature importance analysis shows log-discrepancy and singular fiber multiplicity are top predictors; explicit flux validation on 3–4 high-scoring models confirms ≥80% of topological predictions (chirality index and Yukawa rank match within ±1).
experiment.expected_negative: Topological predictor achieves <0.5 Precision or <0.4 Recall on holdout set; feature importance shows no topological feature has >0.1 importance; flux validation reveals topological predictions wrong by >2 orders in chirality or Yukawa rank; suggests log-geometric invariants are decorrelated from physical SM filters.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: Topological features (intersection numbers, log-discrepancies, Kodaira fiber types) have no predictive power for SM-compatibility (3 chiralities + Yukawa rank ≥5); classifier performs at chance level (Precision ≈ baseline ≈ 0.3–0.4, no better than random guessing).
experiment.statistical_test: Binary classification with 8-model holdout test: report confusion matrix, compute exact Precision = TP/(TP+FP), Recall = TP/(TP+FN), F₁ = 2(Prec·Rec)/(Prec+Rec). Reject H₀ if F₁ > 0.60 and Recall ≥ 0.50 (equivalent to >50% sensitivity in SM filtering). Compute 95% binomial confidence intervals on TP/FP/FN counts. No frequentist p-value (deterministic topological input, small sample); use exact hypergeometric test for feature importance significance if needed.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Topological predictor achieves F₁-score ≥0.65 vs. chance F₁ ≈0.35 (95% → 45% improvement in harmonic mean of precision & recall); Recall ≥0.50 vs. chance ≈0.30 (67% improvement in true positive rate). This requires n=8 holdout sufficient only under strong assumption of topological separability; if effect size is smaller, model likely lacks discriminative power.
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Small sample (39 models total, 8 holdout) limits formal power calculation. Assumption: if topological features truly causally constrain chirality, effect size (Cohen's h or Cramer's V for binary outcome) should be moderate-to-large (h > 0.5, V > 0.35). Under binomial model with 8 holdout tests and true classifier accuracy 75% (vs. null 50%), statistical power ≈ 0.72 (two-sided test, α=0.05 via exact binomial test). Sensitivity is limited by small holdout set; recommend replicating with next batch of χ=−6 polytopes (>50) if initial result is marginal (F₁ = 0.55–0.65).
limitations: Small sample size (39 models, 8 holdout): conclusions must be qualified as exploratory; formal power to detect effect size h>0.5 is ~72%; results should be validated on independent F-theory model set.
Ground-truth labels (chirality, Yukawa rank) from heterogeneous sources (explicit flux, heterotic duality, literature); some may be incomplete or approximate; explicit recomputation on subset needed.

Topological features extracted from singular fiber types are coarse; finer data (e.g., full monodromy matrices, discriminant Newton polytope geometry) may be more predictive but require deeper algebraic geometry work.

Yukawa rank ≥5 is necessary but not sufficient for realistic SM Yukawa textures; Yukawa matrix zeros (texture zeros) require additional data (flux quanta, Wilson lines) beyond topological invariants—experiment tests prediction of rank, not texture.
Model selection bias: χ = −6 elliptically fibered subset may have special properties not shared by wider CY3 landscape; generalizability to other χ, base surfaces, or fibration types unclear.

Computational cost estimate (O(10²) vs. O(10⁵)) assumes intersection computation is fast; actual runtime depends on implementation and base surface complexity; empirical timing on all 39 models required.
No cross-validation on training set due to small size (31 models); validation/test splits may overfit; consider repeated stratified k-fold (k≤5) for robustness.
experiment.requires_followup: Hypothesis predicts that topological filtering can identify SM-compatible models; full confirmation requires: (1) Explicit flux scanning on ≥3 models scored high by topological classifier, to validate chirality index and Yukawa rank predictions. (2) If topological predictor succeeds on flux validation, apply to larger CY3 samples (χ = −8, −10, or extended χ = −6 scan) to test generalizability. (3) Integrate discrete symmetry analysis (proton decay, anomaly cancellation) into framework: test whether vanishing theorems on log resolutions predict absence of dangerous dimension-4,5 proton-decay operators. (4) Connect to moduli stabilization: test whether log-geometric obstructions (e.g., vanishing Kummer surfaces arising from singular fibers) predict or constrain LVS/KKLT vacua in the Yukawa sector. This is a computational proxy for the full physics; wet lab = not applicable (theoretical physics).

hypotheses.source_question: Do the intrinsic method characteristics of string-theory-based vacuum selection criteria causally determine whether different filtering approaches yield consistent SM-like predictions, and can this consistency (or lack thereof) be predicted from topological invariants alone without explicit computation of moduli stabilization?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that intrinsic topological invariants of Calabi-Yau threefolds (Hodge numbers, Picard lattice rank, toric fan structure) causally determine inter-method consistency in SM-like vacuum selection, such that polytopes with high topological constraint rank will exhibit >70% agreement between heterotic, F-theory, and spectral-cover filtering outcomes at Levels 0–2, while unconstrained polytopes exhibit <40% agreement, independent of computational precision or method-specific heuristics.
hypotheses.mechanism: Topological invariants constrain the fiber types available to an elliptic fibration via Kodaira classification, which restricts the gauge algebras and U(1) embeddings that any method can discover. When the Picard lattice rank and Hodge diamond force a narrow family of Weierstrass models and line-bundle cohomologies, all methods converge to the same candidate set because the underlying geometric structure admits few degrees of freedom. Conversely, high-dimensional moduli spaces permit multiple valid Yukawa textures and hypercharge embeddings, causing methods to diverge when optimizing by different criteria. This predicts a monotonic relationship: topological constraint reduces moduli dimension, forcing method agreement.
hypotheses.prediction: Polytopes with Picard rank ≤ 2 and h11 + h21 ≤ 30 will show Jaccard overlap ≥ 0.70 across all four methods at Levels 0-1, whereas polytopes with Picard rank ≥ 4 and h11 + h21 ≥ 50 will show overlap ≤ 0.40. Topological features (Hodge numbers, Picard rank, toric fan complexity) will explain ≥55% of variance in inter-method consistency (adjusted R-squared > 0.55).
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If low-constraint polytopes (Picard rank ≥ 4, h11 + h21 ≥ 50) exhibit Jaccard overlap ≥ 0.65, or if high-constraint polytopes (Picard rank ≤ 2, h11 + h21 ≤ 30) exhibit overlap ≤ 0.45, the hypothesis is refuted. Additionally, if topological features explain <35% of consistency variance (adjusted R-squared < 0.35), the causal claim is falsified.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Adjusted R-squared > 0.55 for topological features predicting consistency; Jaccard index difference between high-constraint and low-constraint groups ≥ 0.25 (Cohen's h ≈ 0.50); correlation between Picard rank and consistency ≥ |r| = 0.45 (p < 0.05, two-tailed).

experiment.approach: Implement a three-phase computational study: (1) Apply four independently validated filtering pipelines (heterotic line-bundle slope stability, F-theory Weierstrass model construction, spectral cover chirality, ML-assisted bundle stability) to 120 reflexive polytopes from Kreuzer-Skarke database, computing Level-0 and Level-1 filtering outcomes. (2) Quantify pairwise method agreement via Jaccard index for each polytope and compute topological feature vectors. (3) Model consistency as a function of topological features via logistic regression and multiple linear regression, testing the causal prediction.
steps: Retrieve 120 reflexive polytopes with χ in {-6, -8, -10} from Kreuzer-Skarke database; stratify by Picard rank (<=2, 3, >=4). Compute Hodge numbers (h11, h21), Picard lattice rank, and toric fan complexity for all candidates.

For each polytope construct all elliptic fibrations using toric Weierstrass database. Apply heterotic line-bundle filter: compute slopes of stable bundles with rank-4 structure group, filter by degree >=0 and mu-stability margin >=0.1.
Apply F-theory filter: enumerate Weierstrass models with smooth discriminant locus; classify Kodaira fiber types; extract gauge algebra from I5, I6, I7, I8 fibers for su(3) ⊕ su(2) requirement.
Apply spectral cover filter: construct su(5) spectral covers compatible with elliptic fibration; compute breaking lines via monodromy loci; identify su(3) ⊕ su(2) subgroups post-Wilson-line breaking.
Apply ML filter using trained heterotic-bundle predictor: score each polytope for SM-like bundle existence via learned Hodge-number features.

For each method pair (M1, M2) compute Jaccard index J(M1, M2) = |SM-L0(M1) intersection SM-L0(M2)| / |SM-L0(M1) union SM-L0(M2)| at Level 0. Repeat at Level 1 (hypercharge U(1)Y embedding). Average to obtain per-polytope consensus score C-poly.

Construct feature matrix X with 12 topological invariants per polytope: h11, h21, h11+h21, Picard rank ρ, product h11*h21, Euler characteristic χ, toric fan size, Gorenstein index, intersection matrix rank, polytope diameter, number of lattice points, K3 fiber genus. Normalize to z-scores.

Perform multiple linear regression: C-poly ~ β0 + β1*h11 + β2*h21 + β3*ρ + β4*fan-size + β5*Gorenstein + ε. Report R-squared, adjusted R-squared, p-values, and AIC. Compute variance inflation factors.
Perform logistic regression (high vs. low consistency, threshold C > 0.55): logit(P(high)) = β0 + β1*ρ + β2*(h11+h21) + β3*fan-size + ε. Report odds ratios, 95% CIs, and AUC.
Construct decision tree (CART, max-depth=4) with topological features as regressors. Prune via 5-fold cross-validation. Report feature importances and split hierarchy.
Compute Pearson and Spearman correlations between each topological feature and C-poly. Identify univariate predictors significant at p < 0.05 with Bonferroni correction (α = 0.05/12).

Test causal direction via mediation analysis: Does Picard rank indirectly affect consistency through constraints on Weierstrass model family? Estimate indirect effect and bias-corrected bootstrap CI (5000 resamples).

Perform sensitivity analysis: (a) Vary filtering thresholds (slope μ in [-0.3, 0.3], discriminant tolerance ±2%); recompute Jaccard indices and test R-squared stability. (b) Stratify by χ value to test for confounding. (c) Recompute on Hodge-symmetric polytope subset to control for database artifacts.
tools: Kreuzer-Skarke reflexive polytope database (PALP binary and Python wrapper)
toric-Weierstrass database (Taylor-Wang, arXiv:1409.8652)
SageMath 10+ for polytope geometry and elliptic curve models
TOPCOM for triangulation and toric fan enumeration
CyTools for Hodge numbers and Picard lattice computation
Custom Python line-bundle classifier (slope calculation, mu-stability check)
F-theory Kodaira fiber classifier (discriminant valuation, monodromy identification)
Spectral cover construction tool via heterotic-F-theory duality
Pre-trained PyTorch ML bundle predictor (Lukas et al. model)
scikit-learn for regression, decision trees, cross-validation, ROC curves
scipy.stats for correlation analysis and mediation tests
statsmodels for regression diagnostics and model selection
Jupyter notebooks for reproducible analysis with GitHub version control
experiment.estimated_effort: 8-10 weeks compute time on HPC cluster (approximately 5000 parallel analyses of polytope families; 2-4 core-hours each; 2 weeks for analysis and visualization).
experiment.data_requirements: Kreuzer-Skarke database (500 MB, public); pre-computed Weierstrass model families (1 GB); line-bundle cohomology tables (100 MB per polytope, computed on-the-fly); pre-trained ML model weights (50 MB). Total: 10-50 GB, manageable on standard academic HPC.
experiment.expected_positive: Multiple regression yields adjusted R-squared > 0.55; Picard rank shows significant correlation with consistency (p < 0.05); high-constraint polytopes show Jaccard overlap ≥ 0.70; low-constraint polytopes show overlap ≤ 0.40; decision tree AUC ≥ 0.75; mediation analysis confirms Picard rank indirectly affects consistency via Weierstrass family dimensionality (bias-corrected CI excludes zero).
experiment.expected_negative: Adjusted R-squared < 0.35 for topological features; Picard rank shows no significant correlation with consistency (p > 0.20); high-constraint and low-constraint groups show indistinguishable Jaccard distributions (overlap 0.50-0.60 for both); decision tree AUC < 0.65; sensitivity analysis shows Jaccard changes >0.20 under ±20% threshold variation. These outcomes refute the causal claim and suggest method divergence is driven by computational artifacts rather than topological structure.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H0: Topological invariants do NOT causally influence inter-method consistency in SM-like vacuum filtering. Consistency outcomes are conditionally independent of topological feature vectors, and explained variance ≤ 35% (adjusted R-squared ≤ 0.35).
experiment.statistical_test: Multiple linear regression F-test for overall model significance (H0: all β coefficients = 0, α = 0.05). Logistic regression Wald test for individual predictors (α = 0.05, two-tailed). Spearman rank correlation for Picard rank versus Jaccard index (ρ, α = 0.0042 after Bonferroni correction for 12 features). Decision tree AUC via 5-fold cross-validation with bootstrap CI (2000 resamples). Mediation indirect effect via bias-corrected percentile bootstrap (5000 resamples), refuted if CI includes zero.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Adjusted R-squared > 0.55 (Cohen's f-squared = 0.122, medium effect); Picard rank-consistency correlation |r| ≥ 0.45 (p < 0.05, two-tailed, N=120); Jaccard difference between constraint groups Δ-J ≥ 0.25 (Cohen's h ≥ 0.50). For logistic regression: odds ratio (Picard rank) ≥ 1.8 (95% CI excludes 1.0). For decision tree: AUC ≥ 0.75 (95% CI excludes 0.65).
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Sample size N=120 polytopes, stratified by Picard rank and χ. Power for Pearson r=0.45, α=0.05, two-tailed: power≈0.88 (G*Power 3.1). Power for multiple regression with 6 predictors, f-squared=0.15, α=0.05: power≈0.92. Logistic regression detecting OR=1.8, α=0.05: requires N≈70; N=120 is over-powered. Convergence criterion: β estimates stable to 4 decimal places across 10 random initializations; residuals pass Breusch-Pagan test (p>0.10); Cook's distance < 4/N=0.033 for all observations.
limitations: Level-0 and Level-1 filters are topologically transparent; Level-2 (chirality index) and Levels 3-6 (Yukawa rank, proton decay, moduli stabilization) may exhibit different consistency patterns and require separate analysis.

Kodaira fiber classification is heuristic and may misidentify fiber types at mild singularities; disagreement between methods on fiber type could arise from numerical precision rather than topological obstruction.
Line-bundle slope stability is computed on abstract toric resolution; physical metrics and Kaehler moduli may alter stability conclusions, introducing method-specific biases.

Spectral cover construction and Wilson line breaking require choice of base for spectral cover family; different choices may yield different SM-like candidates even on the same polytope, confounding method-independent consistency.
ML predictor is trained on subset of heterotic database; performance on polytopes under-represented in training data may be unreliable, introducing systematic bias in method agreement.
Weierstrass models for a given polytope are not unique (multiple sections, choice of coordinates); different choices may yield different gauge algebras, making 'true' SM candidate set ambiguous.
Cross-method validation assumes all four pipelines are equally reliable; if one method has systematic bugs or unfounded assumptions, consistency metrics will be inflated or deflated spuriously.
Stratification by χ value may not control for other confounders (e.g., K3 fiber genus, discriminant complexity); residual confounding could weaken causal inference.
experiment.requires_followup: Computational results identify topological feature thresholds that predict high-consistency polytopes. Follow-up: (1) Heterotic bundle construction and explicit Yukawa coupling computation on high-consensus polytopes to verify SM vacua exist and survive Levels 2-4 filters. (2) F-theory-heterotic duality check on 3-5 test cases: compare spectral cover and line-bundle moduli dimensions, test for equivalence under heterotic-F-theory correspondence. (3) Direct metric computation (Ricci-flat or Kaehler-Einstein approximations) on selected polytopes to validate topological predictions against geometric stability. These wet-lab style validations are essential to confirm causal hypothesis before claiming topological determinism of method consistency.

hypotheses.source_question: Does the embedding of SU(2) gauge factors within larger SU(N) GUT structures (particularly SU(5)) provide a predictive constraint on which F-theory base geometries can produce Standard Model vacua, and can this constraint be formalized as a necessary topological/lattice condition independent of explicit Yukawa computation?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that the geometric embeddability of SU(2) ⊂ SU(N) gauge factor chains within a toric F-theory base is *causally constrained* by lattice-level conditions on the base polytope (specifically: divisor class rank ≥ rank(SU(2)) + rank(SU(3)) and Mori cone membership of certain intersection pairings), and that bases violating these conditions are *incapable* of supporting Standard Model-viable Yukawa textures regardless of flux choice, thereby eliminating them from the SM vacuum candidate pool before Weierstrass model construction.
hypotheses.mechanism: Embedding SU(2) ⊂ SU(N) requires resolving overlapping singularities on distinct divisors of the toric base; the resolution is geometrically feasible only if the base polytope's divisor class rank and Mori cone structure admit simultaneous positive intersection numbers for the required resolution curves. Bases lacking these lattice properties cannot support the requisite SU(2)×SU(3) factorization and thus cannot produce chiral spectrum matching, which causally *blocks* SM-like Yukawa hierarchies downstream.
hypotheses.prediction: At least 30% of the 39 χ = −6 elliptic fibrations marked by CyTools as SU(2)⊕SU(3)-bearing will be re-classified as geometrically *ineligible* for SU(5) GUT breaking when screened against lattice embedding conditions (specifically: divisor class rank < 8 OR Mori cone does not contain intersection pairings for both SU(2) and SU(3) resolution), and for those bases, explicit Weierstrass Yukawa rank analysis will confirm absence of viable SM textures (no three-generation chiral spectrum with correct hypercharge embedding).
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If fewer than 15% (i.e., < 6 of 39) polytopes are identified as lattice-ineligible by the geometric pre-filter, AND simultaneously all 39 bases pass a full Weierstrass + Yukawa rank test confirming viable SM chirality and hypercharge, then the hypothesis is refuted: the SU(2)⊂SU(N) embedding constraint does not causally gate SM viability, and the χ = −6 phenomenon reflects either combinatorial accident or Kodaira permissiveness (supporting scenario B).
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Geometric pre-filter eliminates ≥30% of candidates (≥12 of 39 bases); among lattice-ineligible bases, ≥80% fail Weierstrass Yukawa rank test (i.e., do not support three chiral generations with correct SU(2)L × U(1)Y hypercharge). Correlation between lattice ineligibility and Yukawa failure: Cramér's V ≥ 0.4 (moderate-to-strong association).

experiment.approach: Extract and classify the 39 χ = −6 toric bases from CyTools output; compute lattice invariants (divisor class rank, Mori cone generators, intersection pairings) for each base; apply a lattice-level pre-filter (embeddability criterion based on SU(2)⊂SU(N) resolution geometry); compare filter predictions against explicit Weierstrass + chirality + hypercharge tests to quantify correlation and identify false positives/negatives.
steps: Step 1: Parse CyTools output for the 39 χ = −6 elliptically fibered CY3 polytopes; extract toric base geometry (ambient dimension, polytope vertices, normal fan, Mori cone description).
Step 2: For each base, compute divisor class rank (number of independent divisor classes in Pic(X_base)) using standard toric geometry (lattice point enumeration, fan cohomology).

Step 3: Compute the Mori cone generators (extremal rays of curves with non-negative intersection against all divisors) for each base polytope using secondary polytope or standard integer programming methods.

Step 4: Formalize the SU(2)⊂SU(5) embedding criterion: identify the minimal set of divisor pairs (D_weak, D_strong) required to resolve SU(2)×SU(3)×U(1) singularities without collision; check whether the Mori cone contains curves C with C·D_weak > 0 and C·D_strong > 0 simultaneously for at least 2 independent curve classes (necessary for independent SU(2) and SU(3) resolution).

Step 5: Apply the geometric pre-filter: classify each of 39 bases as *lattice-eligible* (Mori cone membership conditions satisfied + divisor class rank ≥ 8) or *lattice-ineligible* (fails one or both conditions).

Step 6: For each of the 39 bases, construct the Weierstrass model using toric CY equations; compute the divisor-class spectral cover for an SU(5) GUT structure (or SU(2)×SU(3)×U(1) directly); calculate the chiral index χ(R) for each matter representation (using Chern class formulas from toric divisors).

Step 7: For each base, extract hypercharge U(1)_Y as a linear combination of the U(1) generator and SU(2)_L, SU(3) Cartan factors; screen for models where rank(Yukawa coupling matrix restricted to 3-generation matter) ≥ 3 in the up-quark sector (necessary condition for viable top mass and CKM mixing).

Step 8: Cross-tabulate geometric pre-filter classification (Step 5) against Yukawa viability (Step 7); compute contingency table: {lattice-eligible, Yukawa-viable}, {lattice-eligible, Yukawa-inviable}, {lattice-ineligible, Yukawa-viable}, {lattice-ineligible, Yukawa-inviable}.

Step 9: Compute Cramér's V statistic and Fisher's exact p-value for association between lattice ineligibility and Yukawa failure; estimate positive predictive value (PPV) and negative predictive value (NPV) of the geometric pre-filter as a discriminant for SM viability.
Step 10: Repeat steps 1–9 on a holdout validation set of ≥20 additional χ = −6 (or χ = −4) bases not used in formulating the filter, to assess generalization and avoid circular reasoning.
tools: CyTools (polytope enumeration and elliptic fibration classification)
PALP (Kreuzer-Skarke database queries, toric polytope geometry)
Macaulay2 or CoCoA (toric divisor class computation, Mori cone generation)
TOPCOM (secondary polytope for Mori cone generators)
Singular/Magma (Weierstrass model construction from toric CY equations)
Custom Python scripts (chiral index calculation via toric Chern classes, hypercharge embedding, Yukawa matrix rank)
SageMath (lattice operations, fan membership testing, contingency table analysis)
experiment.estimated_effort: 3–4 weeks (2 weeks data extraction & toric geometry computation for 39 bases; 1.5 weeks Weierstrass & Yukawa analysis; 0.5 week validation on holdout set and statistical analysis).
experiment.data_requirements: CyTools output (polytope coordinates and Hodge numbers for 39 χ = −6 models); Kreuzer-Skarke database access; toric fan/Mori cone generators (computed de novo or via TOPCOM); no proprietary data required.
experiment.expected_positive: Contingency table shows ≥70% of lattice-ineligible bases fail Yukawa test (Cramér's V ≥ 0.4, p < 0.05); lattice-eligible bases show ≥60% Yukawa viability; geometric pre-filter correctly predicts ≥80% of the 39 models' Yukawa fate; validation on holdout set confirms ≥75% accuracy, establishing the embedding constraint as a causal gate on SM viability.
experiment.expected_negative: Contingency table shows no significant association (Cramér's V < 0.2, p > 0.10) between lattice ineligibility and Yukawa failure; lattice-eligible and lattice-ineligible bases show similar Yukawa success rates (≈50% both); geometric pre-filter has <60% predictive accuracy; validation set accuracy drops below 65%, indicating that SU(2)⊂SU(N) lattice constraints are not causal discriminants of SM viability (scenario B: Kodaira permissiveness or chance dominates).
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The divisor class rank, Mori cone structure, and SU(2)⊂SU(N) embedding lattice conditions of a toric base are *statistically independent* of whether the base supports a viable SM Yukawa texture (i.e., three chiral generations with correct hypercharge and top ≫ bottom ≫ electron hierarchy). Equivalently: the SU(2)⊂SU(N) embedding constraint is not a causal filter on SM viability; it may correlate with Yukawa failure but does not cause it.
experiment.statistical_test: Fisher's exact test for 2×2 contingency table (lattice-eligible/ineligible × Yukawa-viable/inviable); two-tailed, α = 0.05. Secondary test: Cramér's V effect size (target V ≥ 0.4 for moderate association). Holdout validation: binomial test of prediction accuracy (null: p = 0.5, target: ≥75% accuracy, n ≥ 20, one-tailed α = 0.05).
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Cramér's V ≥ 0.4 (moderate association); this corresponds to approximately 30–40% difference in Yukawa viability rate between lattice-eligible and ineligible groups in a sample of n = 39. For holdout validation: ≥75% prediction accuracy (binomial test, one-tailed, α = 0.05, n ≥ 20 requires ≥16 correct predictions).
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Primary analysis: n = 39 (fixed, all available χ = −6 models). Fisher's exact test is exact (no assumptions); power is high for moderate effects (V ≥ 0.4). Contingency table expected cell counts: if true association V = 0.4, expected cells are ~5–15 per cell, adequate for Fisher's test. Holdout validation: n ≥ 20 at 80% power to detect p ≠ 0.5 with α = 0.05 requires ≥16 successes (binomial test; power = 0.81 for p = 0.75, n = 20, one-tailed).
limitations: Lattice embeddability is a necessary but not sufficient condition for SM viability; the pre-filter may eliminate candidates that Yukawa analysis could have saved (false positives for ineligibility).

Weierstrass models constructed from toric CY equations may not explore the full moduli space of flux choices; Yukawa rank could depend sensitively on flux configuration, which is not systematically varied here.
Hypercharge embedding is model-dependent (choice of U(1) generator and SU(2)_L/SU(3) Cartan combinations); misidentification of hypercharge could bias Yukawa viability assessment.
The sample size (n = 39) is modest; contingency table cells may have low expected counts if the true association is weak, reducing power.
Chirality calculation via Chern classes assumes no torsion in H²(base); some bases may have torsion that complicates the formula.

Validation on χ = −4 bases (rather than a held-out subset of χ = −6) tests generalization across Euler characteristic but not statistical independence; internal cross-validation (k-fold) would strengthen this.
experiment.requires_followup: If computational pre-filter is validated (Cramér's V ≥ 0.4, holdout accuracy ≥75%), follow-up work should include: (1) Explicit flux scanning on a subset of 5–10 lattice-ineligible bases to test whether non-generic flux choices can rescue Yukawa viability (quantify fraction that Weierstrass alone missed). (2) Formalization of the lattice condition as a theorem (conjecture-to-proof level) using representation-theoretic methods in toric geometry. (3) Application to larger databases (all χ ≤ 0, all toric bases in F-theory) to assess whether χ = −6 uniqueness is real or artifact. (4) If the geometric pre-filter proves robust, implement as a hardened CyTools filter and run large-scale scan to estimate the density of SM-viable vacua in the landscape.

hypotheses.source_question: Does spontaneous proton decay in SM vacua arise necessarily from B−L breaking, or can baryon-number violation occur through alternative mechanisms (e.g., discrete symmetry remnants, higher-dimensional operators) that preserve B−L at the level of the fundamental Lagrangian?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that spontaneous proton decay in SM-like vacua derived from χ = −6 elliptically fibered CY3 threefolds arises necessarily from continuous B−L gauge symmetry breaking, not discrete remnants; specifically, models with anomaly-free continuous B−L factors embedded in their U(1) structure will exhibit suppressable proton decay rates (< 10³¹ yr), while models lacking continuous B−L will show rapid decay (> 10³⁰ yr) even when discrete symmetries are present.
hypotheses.mechanism: Continuous B−L gauge symmetry protects baryon number at tree level by forbidding dimension-4 and dimension-5 proton-decay operators before spontaneous breaking; upon B−L breaking via scalar vacuum expectation value, protection shifts to discrete remnants (Z_N subgroups from center quotients), whose action on fermion representations is algebraically weaker, allowing higher-order operators to dominate. Discrete symmetries alone, without prior continuous B−L embedding, provide no tree-level protection and permit leading-order operators; thus proton decay rates scale inversely with the order of the discrete subgroup. The causal chain is: B−L embedding structure (gauge algebra) → operator suppression hierarchy → effective proton lifetime.
hypotheses.prediction: For the 39 χ = −6 elliptic CY3 models in the sample: models with rank-1 (or higher) anomaly-free continuous B−L factor will show computed proton decay lifetime > 10³¹ years in at least 80% of cases; models with no continuous B−L (only discrete remnants) will show lifetime < 10³⁰ years in at least 75% of cases. The median proton lifetime will differ by > 3 orders of magnitude between the two groups (p < 0.01, Mann–Whitney U test).
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If > 50% of models with continuous B−L embedded in their gauge algebra produce computed proton decay rates > 10³⁰ yr (faster than protected regime), OR if > 50% of models lacking continuous B−L produce rates < 10³¹ yr (consistent with B−L protection), the hypothesis is refuted. Equivalently: if correlation coefficient between 'has continuous B−L factor' and 'log₁₀(proton lifetime)' is < 0.4 across the sample, hypothesis is rejected.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Spearman ρ > 0.5 between presence of continuous B−L and proton lifetime (log scale), or equivalently median lifetime difference > 2.5 orders of magnitude (10³¹ vs 10²⁸·⁵ yr) with Mann–Whitney U test p < 0.01 and effect-size rank-biserial correlation > 0.4.

experiment.approach: Computational pipeline: for each of 39 χ = −6 elliptic CY3 models, extract anomaly-free U(1) structure via toric geometry and linear algebra; identify continuous B−L factors; compute discrete center-quotient structure post-breaking; classify leading proton-decay operators using SU(3)×SU(2)×U(1)_Y selection rules; estimate decay rates via effective operator analysis and correlation with discrete symmetry order. Stratify sample by presence/absence of continuous B−L and compare lifetime distributions.
steps: Step 1: From CyTools output for each model, extract the full anomaly-free U(1) lattice (rank r_U(1)) and Kodaira fiber types. Verify that all 39 models contain su(3)⊕su(2) factors and identify the dimension of the hypercharge/right-handed neutrino plane.

Step 2: For each model, enumerate all rank-1 anomaly-free U(1) combinations and test whether any linear combination couples to baryons only (∂Q_B/∂φ≠0, ∂Q_L/∂φ=0 mod discrete). Classify models as 'has continuous B−L' or 'lacks continuous B−L'.

Step 3: Determine the discrete symmetry group acting on the SM matter spectrum. Extract center quotients Z_m ⊂ SU(3)/SU(2)/U(1)_Y and compute their intersection with the discrete subgroup of the B−L factor (if present) or with GUT-residual discrete symmetries (if B−L absent). Record the order of the baryon-number-protecting discrete subgroup.

Step 4: For each model, write down dimension-4 (QQQL, UUDC) and dimension-5 (QQQL/M_GUT, UUDC/M_GUT) proton-decay operators. Apply the discrete symmetry group and compute the charge of each operator under the active discrete symmetries. If continuous B−L is present, show that tree-level dimension ≤ 4 operators are forbidden before B−L breaking; compute the order of suppression after breaking via the branching ratio of the B−L-breaking scalar to discrete remnants.

Step 5: Estimate effective proton decay rate R_p = (α_s/π)^k × (M_X/M_Pl)^n × (M_proton / M_operator)^3 for each model, where k is the loop order of the dominant amplitude, M_X is the scale at which baryon-number violation becomes effective, and n parameterizes GUT coupling unification. Set M_X = M_GUT ≈ 10^16 GeV for models with continuous B−L embedding (GUT-like protection); set M_X = M_B−L_breaking or M_Pl for models with discrete remnants only. Convert to proton lifetime τ_p = 1/R_p.

Step 6: Classify each model as 'B−L protected' (continuous B−L + dominant discrete remnant) or 'discrete-only protected' (no continuous B−L, discrete symmetries only). Construct contingency table: {has continuous B−L × log₁₀(τ_p)} with bin edges at 10²⁸, 10³⁰, 10³². Compute Spearman rank correlation ρ and Mann–Whitney U statistic.

Step 7: Generate scatter plot and cumulative distribution functions for both groups. Measure effect size via rank-biserial correlation r_rb = 1 − (2U) / (n₁ × n₂). Report 95% confidence intervals on medians via bootstrap (10,000 resamples).

Step 8: Perform sensitivity analysis: vary M_X by ±1 order of magnitude and repeat Steps 5–7. Check robustness of classification across parameter choices. Identify models near decision boundary (τ_p ≈ 10³⁰ yr) that would flip classification under reasonable assumptions.
tools: CyTools (https://github.com/ToricVarieties/CyTools) for polytope geometry and Kodaira fiber extraction
SageMath (linear algebra over Z for U(1) lattice and anomaly cancellation)
GAP (group theory for discrete symmetry quotients and character tables)
Custom Python script: U(1) classifier (enumerate anomaly-free combinations), operator_analyzer (dimension-4/5 selection rules), decay_rate_estimator (effective operator scaling)
Kreuzer–Skarke database (h¹¹, h²¹ for all 39 models)
Published F-theory/heterotic model data (Wilson lines, hypercharge embeddings, GUT breaking modes) from Braun/He/Ovrut, Cvetic/Halverson/Lin databases
experiment.estimated_effort: 2–4 weeks: Step 1–3 (polytope + U(1) extraction) ~3–5 days; Step 4–5 (operator analysis + decay rate computation) ~5–7 days; Step 6–8 (statistics + sensitivity) ~3–4 days. Bottleneck: manual verification of discrete symmetry action on matter multiplets for each model (1–2 hrs/model = ~2–3 days parallelizable).
experiment.data_requirements: CyTools database (free, open); Kreuzer–Skarke h-vectors; published F-theory/heterotic model metadata (Braun et al. spectral cover models, Cvetic/Halverson toric base data). No proprietary data required; all intermediate outputs (U(1) lattices, discrete groups, operator charges) can be tabulated and published.
experiment.expected_positive: 39 models split into two groups (e.g., 28 with continuous B−L, 11 without). Median proton lifetimes: B−L-protected group median ≥ 10³¹ yr (IQR 10³⁰·⁵–10³¹·⁵), discrete-only group median ≤ 10²⁹ yr (IQR 10²⁸–10³⁰). Mann–Whitney U test p < 0.01; Spearman ρ > 0.5; rank-biserial r_rb > 0.4. >80% of B−L-protected models produce τ_p > 10³¹ yr; >75% of discrete-only produce τ_p < 10³⁰ yr.
experiment.expected_negative: Overlap of distributions: median lifetimes differ by < 1 order of magnitude, or p-value Mann–Whitney > 0.05. Spearman ρ < 0.3.
